INJR, INJR General
50.1 INJR General
� General Information
50.1.1 1.1 General
The aggregate INJR ? INJection Realisation - concerns the realisation of the fuel mass and phasing set point
requests. The main objective of INJR aggregate is to provide the inverse model of an injection valve (transfer
function that delivers injection time dependent on the fuel mass set point and including delay time, pressure,
temperature, etc. in?uences).
Injector model 
(INJR)
fuel mass 
(from Aggr. FMSP)
injection time 
(to basic software )
Figure 50.1.1: Simpli?ed overview of TI calculation
INJR aggregate supports dual injection systems MPI and HPDI.
Basic injection system overview:
The injection system is split into many components: INJR ASW, INJ I/O driver (BSW), Injector controller hard-
ware (electronic, Fast ADC/bank and ATIC) and fuel injector (SDI/MPI injection valve).
The INJR ASW function (ASW) provides all parameters to the I/O driver (BSW) needed to generate the proper
injection pulses, I/O driver (BSW) controls the injection hardware (electronic, Fast ADC/bank and ATIC) in a way
that generates the proper requested injection signal of the fuel injector.

50.1.2 1.2 Objectives of aggregate
INJR is supporting a multi pulse strategy for HPDI and a single pulse strategy for MPI. Depending on the engine
and the needed combustion strategy a set of combustion modes has to be de?ned which are managed by
the CBMD aggregate. From point of view of injection realisation a combustion mode corresponds to a speci?c
injection mode de?ned by the involved injection system (MPI, DI, MPI and DI), a speci?c number of injection
pulses (e.g. DI double injection), and a speci?c phasing strategy (e.g. DI double injection with one SOI based
pulse, and one EOI based pulse ? SOI = start of injection, EOI = end of injection). The de?nition of the injection
modes is achieved by a proper con?guration of the INJR aggregate. The ?exibility to support an arbitrary set
of injection modes is achieved by the so called multi-pulse concept.
Important features of injection realisation are:
? Calculation of injection timing - realisation of the injection time based on the FMSP requests taking
into consideration the injection valve characteristics (injector dead time correction, pressure correction,
temperature correction, etc. );
? Controlled solenoid injection (COSI) is a control function to adapt the hydraulic injector closing via volt-
age feedback measurement.
? Calculation of injection phasing
- the INJR aggregate contains a set point strategy for the desired injection phasing depending on the
engine operating state and considering the injection phasing limits;
? Injection pulse collision management to solve pulse con?icts, e.g. in case that calculated pulse param-
eters lead to overlapping pulses or pulses out of the injection phase limitation - the desired phasing is
limited to the physically possible range. The range is related to the ?ring top dead centre by an con?g-
urable offset;
? Generation of so called make-up pulses ? additional pulses realised after the standard pulses in the actual
injection mode in order to support highly dynamic situations with a strong torque increase;
? Handling of cylinder switch-on and switch-off - a sophisticated cylinder individual injection deactivation
and activation functionality is available, e.g. for the transition into and from engine pull with fuel cut
off. The number of deactivated/activated cylinders can change smoothly. It is possible to switch off the
injection of an individual injection valve, e.g. in case of mis?re;

INJR, INJR General
? Management and calculation of current pro?le parameters needed for HPDI;
? Electrical diagnosis of the power stage and injection valves - electrical failures are detected by the injec-
tion diagnostic function, there are three different types of diagnosis related to INJR:
? Functional diagnosis - cold start emission reduction strategy (CSERS_INJ) for diagnosis of the requested
multiple injection strategy;
? Handling of speci?c operation modes (e.g. start);
? Synchronisation of injection and ignition control and MPI and SDI control, in order to maintain consis-
tency of control parameters ? especially in transient situations;
During start INJR calculates / updates control parameters with a recurrence of 10 ms, out of start with seg-
ment synchronously, in speci?c situations even half-segment synchronously. Furthermore some events are
generated by IO-driver (e.g. INJ_BAS event) for speci?c calculation tasks. For each injection mode a phasing
limit is speci?ed until which updates of a running injection cycle are proceeded. Therefore at each update
recurrence the actual pulse realization state of the IO-driver is recalculated based on the actual engine position
information
50.1.3 1.3 Aggregate variant
This function is dedicated for solenoid HPDI multiple pulse injection and for an auxiliary MPI single pulse
injection.

50.1.5 1.5 COSI principle
COSI Principle:
Controlled solenoid injection (COSI) is a control function to adapt the hydraulic injector closing via voltage
feedback measurement.

? The idea is to look for a control variable that is directly correlated to the real needle lift behaviour (injector
closing):
TI_EFF = OPP4 ? OPP2 = TI + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN
? TI: refers to TI_MES_H which is the measured injection time between
SOI and EOI
? T_CLOSE: time from EOI until the injector is fully closed, can only be determined by an electrical feedback-
signal
? T_OPEN: time from SOI until the injector is fully opened, predicted by calibration only in current strategy
Figure 50.1.4: COSI principle
Hence,
TI_EFF = TI + T_CLOSE -T_OPEN
TI = TI_EFF - T_CLOSE + T_OPEN

The main in?uences on the injection time:
? MFF including multiplicative MFF-correction

?
1. Differential pressure, rail to cylinder
2. Pressure waves in rail
3. Residual magnetism from previous injection

?
1. Fuel type
2. Fuel temperature
? Injector control
?
1. used current pro?le
2. current driver tolerance
3. temperature of injector coil

? Production tolerance
? needle movement dynamics
? electronic injection driver tolerance

Acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal:
In this module the signal acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal detected via fast ADC is
handled to determine the injector closing time "T_CLOSE" as follow:
Applying one of 6 different approaches algorithm on the measured feedback voltage signal "V_MES" via
(F)ADC in order to determine closing time "T_CLOSE"
Final injection timing:
In this module the calculation of the effective injection time is calculated as follow:
Determination of the effective injection time TI_EFF_SP form of a MFF-characteristic-maps (IP_TI_EFF_MFF_
TEMP_) which depends on a standard fuel mass quantity (MFF_STND_SYN_TMP)including multiplicative MFF-
correction and cylinder individual fuel pressure difference at the injector "PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL" considering the
fuel temperature in?uence TFI_INJ
Figure 50.1.6: MFF characteristic
COSI control:
In this module handles the ?nal procedure for TI_H calculation is done as follow:
TI_H: is the requested injection time between SOI and EOI which is provided to the I/O driver (BSW). In order
to calculate the requested injection time TI_H for a given TI_EFF_SP working curves are introduced.
Working curves (TI_BIT_MID): are rough shape curves which are stored in NVMY over a wide range of in-
?uences quantities as pressure, temperature, etc.. , their axis are TI_DIF, TI_EFF and their origins (starting
points) are TI_0 and T_OPEN, this curves are represented via fast bit-coded adaption.
An example:
CRV1 = {PRS_DIF = 60 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV2 = {PRS_DIF = 100 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV3 = {PRS_DIF = 140 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV4 = {PRS_DIF = 200 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
TI_0: ?rst in?nitesimal opening time of the injector when MFF>= 0.2 mg/stk
T_OPEN_0: opening injection time, when MFF >0.2 mg/stk
TI_DIF: TI_H - TI_0

INJR, INJR General
Figure 50.1.7: Working curves
Procedure of TI_H calculation is done as follow:
? For a given pressure, MFF, pressure difference, temperature, etc.. there is a corresponding working curve
stored in NVMY
? The MFF characteristic yields a TI_EFF_SP (see the left curve at below ?gure )
? Then go right to hit the working curve which yield TI_DIF
? TI_H= TI_DIF + TI_0
TI_H is provided to BSW and to be applied for the current cycle
In case of adaption (control): T_CLOSE and TI_MES_H are measured back from BSW, then calculating TI_EFF
= TI_H_MES + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN, then compare it with requested TI_EFF_SP, if they are not equal the working
curve is updated towards the point (TI_DIF, TI_EFF) depending on the value of the ?lter IP_FAC_FIL_COSI_CTL.
IP_FAC_FIL_COSI_CTL: Filter factor indicates the adaptive percentage for the working curve adaption towards
the new value, acts as low pass ?lter.
Adaption of the working curves using fast bit coded adaption in order to have a reasonable working curves
which re?ects an accurate injected fuel mass.

Centring/Backcentring:
In order to use the same curve for this wide range a procedure named Centring/Back centring is introduced
in order to cover all the possible ranges.
As the rough shape of the working curves are stored in NVMY over a wide range of in?uences quantity, each
working curve covers a wide range of in?uences quantities e.g. CRV1 covers the pressure from 60 bar 10 100
bar and refers to reference condition e.g. 80 bar example: CRV1 covers the pressure range i.e. pressure range
between 60.
So the working curves should be ?normalized? in such a way that the single working curve can re?ect its shape
as good as possible as follow.
Working curves are expanded/shrunken towards TI_EFF and TI_DIF axis in order to cover this wide range, open-
ing time (TI_0, T_OPEN_0)are shifted also depending on the in?uences quantities, hence is shifted depending
on pressure and temperature
TI_EFF at actual condition is centred =>to get TI_DIF_MID at reference condition
TI_DIF_MID (reference condition) is Back centred =>to get TI_DIF_MID at actual condition

INJR COSI (Appl.Inc.):
In this module the project speci?c adaption of the controlled solenoid injection is handled as follow:
? Enabling/Disabling COSI functionality via "C_STATE_COSI_ENA"
? Determination of burst pattern for feedback voltage signal which is used for detecting closing time "T_
CLOSE"
? Determination of the working curves stored in NVMY
? Determination of minimum fuel mass ?ow
INJR COSI manager:
In this module the coordination of the controlled solenoid injection tasks are handled
50.1.6 1.6.1 Injection Time
Injection timing for HPDI without COSI:
The calculation of the inverse model of an injection valve (transfer function that delivers injection time depen-
dent on the fuel mass set point, pressure difference, temperature, etc. in?uences).
The calculation of the injection time is applicable for HPDI system depends on the engine operating state,
which can be changed easily according to the engine needs.
Fuel temperature correction: since the density and viscosity of the fuel depends on the fuel temperature,
there must be a correction of the injection time. This correction is applied in:
FAC_MFF_TFU = IP_FAC_MFF_TEMP_COR(TFU_INJ)
Hint: This is only possible for the NON- COSI - INJR.
Standard fuel mass quantity (MFF_STND_SYN_TMP): consider MFF_SP from FMSP including multiplicative
MFF-correction e.g. from CYBL, CILC)* FAC_RHO_INJ
MFF_STND_SYN = MFF_SP * FAC_RHO_INJ * FAC_TI_BAL
File: 30101R09.00A
12887Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
Fuel pressure correction (PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL): correction factor to take into account the pressure drop at the
injector for each injection cylinder individually.
The pressure drop "PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL" in the injector is the difference between FUP (fuel pressure in the rail) and
the cylinder counter pressure. It is used as input for the injection valve characteristic-map (used by injector
characteristic).
Injection timing for HPDI without COSI:
Injector valve characteristic: calculates the basic injection time in form of an injection valve characteristic-
map IP_TI_4_.... which depends on a standard fuel mass quantity (MFF_STND_SYN_TMP)and cylinder individual
fuel pressure difference at the injector "PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL".
The choice of the injection valve characteristic map additionally depends on the injector current pro?le "NR_
MOD_CUR_IV" as follows:
IP_TI_4_H: injection time as function of fuel mass set point and fuel pressure difference for over pressure injector
current pro?le
IP_TI_4_L: injection time as function of fuel mass set point and fuel pressure difference for low injector current
pro?le
IP_TI_4_OVER_PRS: injection time as function of fuel mass set point and fuel pressure difference for high injector
current pro?le
Injector current pro?le "NR_MOD_CUR_IV" : There can be calibrated different current pro?les which differ with
respect to peak and hold current values and the timing of the individual current phases. At engine start and
low TCO_ST, the Injector current pro?le is clamped to a high current pro?le to warm up all electrical injection
components as fast as possible. Afterwards the choice of the current pro?le dynamically depends on the
combination of the following criteria:
? Value of fuel Pressure (FUP) - FUP-values bigger than C_FUP_H_CUR_OVER_PRS_IV_ACT will lead to an
overpressure current pro?le. At FUP-values bigger than C_FUP_H_CUR_H_IV will lead to a high pressure
current pro?le, otherwise a low pressure current pro?le is taken;
? Biggest TI-value of all injection pulses over all cylinders in the given injection mode - depending on
calibration constant C_TI_HOM_CLC_MAX_CUR_H_IV high TI-values request a switch to a high current
pro?le to avoid undesired injector closing ;
All thresholds are calibratable and applied with a hysteresis to avoid toggling of the current pro?le.

Figure 50.1.10: Final injection timing calculation without COSI
Note: in case COSI function is switched off, TI_EFF_SP does not considers closing and opening times, hence "COSI
control" and "Acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal" modules are not considered in the
calculation. TI_EFF_SP = TI_4 = TI_H i.e. time between electrical SOI and EOI, which is provided to the I/O
drive(BSW).
Injection timing for HPDI with COSI:
Injector valve characteristic: calculates the effective injection time (TI_EFF_SP)in form of a MFF-characteristic-
maps which depends on a standard fuel mass quantity (MFF_STND_SYN_TMP) and cylinder individual fuel
pressure difference at the injector "PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL", in order to consider the fuel temperature in?uence in the
effective injection time calculation an interpolation mechanism is to be executed between three 2-dimensional
maps in function of fuel temperature "TFU_INJ" as follow:
TI_EFF_SP is obtained interpolating the value between three 2-dimensional maps for three reference tempera-
tures (-20.25 �C, 19.5 �C, 79.5 �C). The inputs of the 2D maps are MFF_STND_SYN_TMP and PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL, the
output values are interpolated in function of fuel temperature TFU_INJ in order to consider fuel temperature
(TFU_INJ) in?uence as follow:
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_L(MFF_STND_SYN_TMP, PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference
conditions and a fuel temperature of -20.25 �C;
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_MID_1(MFF_STND_SYN_TMP, PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference
conditions and a fuel temperature of 19.5 �C;
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_H(MFF_STND_SYN_TMP, PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference
conditions and a fuel temperature of 79.5 �C;

Note: in case COSI function is switched on, TI_EFF_SP considers closing and opening times, hence "COSI
control" and "Acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal" modules are considered in the
calculation for TI_H and closing time "T_CLOSE" determination. In this case TI_EFF_SP ?= TI_H
Figure 50.1.11: TI_EFF_SP calculation
TI_H: is the requested injection time between SOI and EOI which is provided to the I/O driver (BSW) and
is determined via stored working curves "TI_BIT_MID" in NVMY depending on injection time in?uences i.e.

in order to cover all the possible ranges as described in chapter 1.5 COSI principle.

TI_MES_H: is the measured back injection time between SOI and EOI from BSW.
T_CLOSE: is the calculated closing time via _ one of 6 different approaches algorithm on the measured feed-
back voltage signal "V_MES" via ADC in module.
T_OPEN: is predicted by calibration in current strategy.
TI_EFF = TI_MES_H + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN.
Figure 50.1.14: TI_EFF calculation

Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

In case of adaption (control): T_CLOSE and TI_MES_H are measured back from BSW, then calculating TI_EFF
= TI_H_MES + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN, then compare it with requested TI_EFF_SP, if they are not equal the working
curve is updated towards the point (TI_DIF, TI_EFF) depending on the value of the ?lter IP_FAC_FIL_COSI_CTL,
in order to have a reasonable working curves which re?ects an accurate injected fuel mass.
Figure 50.1.15: Adaptation mechanism
Injection timing for MPI:
The inverse injection valve characteristics IP_FAC_MFF_TI_STND_H_RNG_MPI is used to calculate the injec-
tion time of MPI valve. It takes into account the valve speci?c information, e.g. available ?ow area, shape
etc and assumes a linear dependency of the injection time on the fuel mass set point. If only one fuel type
is used it is a constant value. If a fuel mixture is taken there are two values. One for 100% gasoline and one
for e.g. 15% gasoline and 85% ethanol. There is a linear interpolation between these two values depending on
the actual fuel composition FAC_AFU_RATIO. This takes into account the change of density, viscosity, etc. with
changing composition. This parameter is calibrated at a reference pressure difference.
FAC_MFF_TI_STND_H_RNG_MPI = IP_FAC_MFF_TI_STND_H_RNG_MPI (FAC_AFU_RATIO)
The injection valve is the boundary between two regions with different pressure levels - fuel rail and intake
manifold. The fuel ?ow depends on the pressure decrease PRS_DEC_INJ_1_HOM_MPI, which occurs from the
fuel point of view when it leaves the rail and enters the intake manifold.
PRS_DEC_INJ_1_HOM_MPI = FUP_MPI - MAP
The inverse injection valve characteristics IP_FAC_MFF_TI_STND_H_RNG_MPI is adapted to the actual pressure
difference PRS_DEC_INJ_1_HOM_MPI by IP_FAC_TI_PRS_MPI. Furthermore density ?uctuations of fuel due to a
variation of the temperature TFU_MPI can be compensated with a factor acting IP_FAC_TI_TEMP_COR_MPI on
the fuel injection time.
FAC_TI_1_PRS_HOM_MPI =
IP_FAC_TI_PRS_MPI(PRS_DEC_INJ_1_HOM_MPI) * IP_FAC_TI_TEMP_COR_MPI(TFU_MPI)
The injection valve is a system with dynamic behaviour. It takes some time till the valve is opened and some
time till it is closed. If e.g. the opening time is bigger than the closing one it is necessary to correct (to extend)
File: 30101R09.00A
12892Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
the injection time by an offset. It essentially depends on the battery voltage VB. There might be some cooling
effects of the mass air ?ow on the injection valve that in?uence the delay time. This is taken into account by a
dependence of the dead time on the intake air temperature TIA_IM and intake air ?ow MAF_MPI.
TI_ADD_DLY_1_HOM_MPI =
IP_TI_ADD_DLY_MPI(VB) + IP_TI_ADD_DLY_TEMP_COR_MPI(TIA_IM, MAF_MPI)
The cylinder individual injection time is then TI_1_HOM_CLC_MPI[x].
TI_1_HOM_CLC_MPI[x] = MFF_SP_1_HOM_MPI[x] *
FAC_MFF_TI_STND_H_RNG_MPI *
FAC_TI_1_PRS_HOM_MPI *
FAC_TI_AFU_MPI +
TI_ADD_DLY_1_HOM_MPI
Note: FACT_TI_AFU_MPI is the injection time correction caused by the alternative fuel, in most of the projects
is stubbed to 1.
There are some additional modi?cations of the injection time as TI_ADD_MPI and TI_FAC_MPI, they allow multi-
plicative and additive corrections by the application system or from external function or devices. They can be
global for all cylinders or cylinder individual.
TI_1_HOM_CLC_MPI[x] is then processed to TI_1_HOM_MPI[x]. Some modi?cations can be needed due to injec-
tion valve parameters, e.g. due to minimum realisable injection time.
Note: There is no pre-injection function for MPI that provides injection if a minimum level of the crankshaft
position synchronisation is reached, as the engine start is managed by HPDI system.
50.1.7 1.6.2 Injection phasing - general information
The INJR aggregate contains a set point strategy for the requested injection phasing. The desired phasing is
limited to the physically possible range. The range is related to the ?ring top dead centre by an con?gurable
offset.
INJR is supporting a multi pulse strategy for HPDI and single pulse for MPI. Also INJR supports the generation
of make up pulses for both systems in dependence on combustion mode.
The phasing set point strategy can be SOI (angle for injection start) or EOI (angle for injection end based),
according to LV_SOI_PLS_REQ. The injection phasing is calculated for dual systems MPI and HPDI depend on
the engine operating state. The set point functionality is placed in the hook module "INJR_REQGNai0", which
can be changed easily according to the project needs.
The fuel can be injected over a range of 720 �CRK. The cylinder individual zero position of this range is de-
?ned via the constants NC_CRK_INJ_REF_TDC and NC_CRK_INJ_BAS_REF with reference to the ignition TDC of
cylinder 0, as described below.

50.1.8 1.6.3 Injection phasing and pulse collision management
The injection phasing functionality calculates and manages the position where an injection pulse is placed.
The realization of these features are neatly connected with the multi pulse concept.
Important topics for injection phasing are:
? Injection pulse types;
? Injection pulse prioritization;
? Continuous line function;
Injection phasing for HPDI
File: 30101R09.00A

expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
Injection pulse types: Each injection pulse is de?ned by an injection time (TI) and a position information. There
are four different types to de?ne the pulse position:
? Type SOI_TI : pulse position is de?ned via absolute start of injection angle;
? Type EOI_TI: pulse position is de?ned via absolute end of injection angle;
? Type T_TI: pulse position is de?ned via delta time to a preceding pulse;
? Type TI_T: pulse position is de?ned via delta time to a following pulse;
The pulse types can be selected to suit the combustion goal- one combination of pulse types represents one
combustion mode.
Injection pulse prioritization: Pulse prioritization is de?ned to avoid pulse collision on a cylinder. For each
combustion mode, one pulse is de?ned as the priority pulse.
In case of pulse collision, the high priority pulse remains and the other pulses will be shifted. Typically only the
?rst or the last pulse can be a high priority pulse.
Continuous line function: At violation of the maximum injection range, the gaps between the pulses will be
reduced to ?t the maximum injection range.
Example: triple injection with SOI_TI, TI_T and EOI_TI pulses, the calibrated pulses are corrected to ?t the
maximum injection range as shown in the ?gure.

Figure 50.1.18: Gap reduction example
In case that gap reduction is utilized (all gaps set to minimum), a ?ag "LV_CRK_DIF_SOI_EOI_LIM" will be raised
to enable torque reduction.
Pulse collision management
Pulse collision management has to ensure that the following restrictions are not violated:
1. No pulse must be performed beyond the injection range limits "SOI_LIM_INJ" and "EOI_LIM_INJ_CYL".
2. A calibrated minimum time C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" must be available between two consecutive pulses.
3. Any violation leads to a shifting or cutting of pulses, in accordance to the following priorities:
4.
? Priority 0: the number of pulses has to be executed as requested;
? Priority1: the correct fuel mass (injection time) of the injection pulses shall have higher priority than
the calibrated pulse phasing;
? Priority 2: phasing of the high priority pulse has to be maintained;
? Priority 3: phasing of low pulses has to be maintained;
File: 30101R09.00A
12896Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
This is ensured by the following pulse collision management algorithm:
1. In case SOI of ?rst pulse is earlier than SOI_LIM, this pulse will be shifted later so that SOI = SOI_LIM. In
case that an overlap with subsequent pulses will result due this shift, these pulses would be shifted later,
from left to right ? until the minimum distance "C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" is reached everywhere.
2. In case EOI of last pulse is later than EOI_LIM, this pulse will be shifted earlier so that EOI = EOI_LIM. In
case that an overlap with preceding pulses will result due this shift, these pulses would be shifted earlier,
from right to left ? until the minimum distance "C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" is reached everywhere.
3. If the sum of all TI + minimum delay time is bigger than the distance EOI_LIM ? SOI_LIM (maximum
injection range completely ?lled) the last pulse is cut.
4. In case of overlapping pulses ( = distance is smaller than C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4), they are shifted away
from the high priority pulse. A high priority pulse is always the ?rst or the last one, and it will keep its
position during shifting. Shifting will begin with the nearest neighbour, then next one and so on, until the
minimum distance C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4 is maintained everywhere.
Important points must be taken into consideration:
? If the ?rst pulse is already at SOI_LIM, shifting will go from left to right ? even if the last pulse would be
high priority (see point 1 above);
? If the last pulse is already at EOI_LIM, shifting will go from right to left ? even if the ?rst pulse would be
high priority (see point 2 above);
Injection phasing for MPI
INJR supports single pulse for MPI additional to multiple pulse concept for HPDI.
One injection pulse per cylinder and per engine working cycle is supported. Also makeup pulses are available
for MPI in dependence on combustion mode and engine state.
The phasing set point strategy can be SOI (angle for injection start) or EOI (angle for injection end based).
The information about the chosen one is in LV_SOI_PLS_REQ. The injection phasing depends on the engine
operating state. The set point functionality is placed in the hook module "Injection phasing (APPL. Inc.) ", which
can be changed easily according to the engine needs.

Continuous line functionality should indicate when the possible injection range is totally exploited. There are
two limiting injection ranges. One range is an electrical limit which is de?ned by NC_CRK_INJ_RNG_MPI and
the gap which is occupied by IO-software and hardware (SOC_INJ_SOI_GAP_MPI). The other limit is the physical
limit which is given by application data (SOI_LIM_HOM_SP_MPI and EOI_LIM_HOM_SP_MPI). The minimum of
these ranges is used to compare whether the limit is reached or not. A hysteresis function could be applied.
50.1.9 1.6.4 Make up pulse
A make-up pulse is an additional injection pulse delivered after the standard pulse in single injection mode.
It can be executed in case that an increase of fuel mass is requested for the actual cycle, but this request is
coming too late to be taken into account for the standard pulse.
For injection time duration of a Make pulse a multiplicative factor FAC_INJ_ADD_PLS for HPDI or FAC_INJ_
ADD_PLS_MPI for MPI can be used. This factor depends on the calibration map IP_FAC_ADD_PLS for HPDI or
IP_FAC_ADD_PLS_MPI for MPI, which can be used to shorten the duration of an additive pulse at higher speed
(set to 0 ms at very high speed).
Make-up pulse position for HPDI:is activated if the con?gurable bit NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_HPDI_ENA in the bit
?eld LF_INJ_CMB_SP is enabled, the determination of the end of injection position for autonomous generated
update pulse is depending on calibrated map "IP_EOI_INJ_UPD_PSN".
Make-up pulse position for MPI: is activated if the con?gurable bit NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_MPI_ENA in the bit
?eld LF_INJ_CMB_SP is enabled, the determination of the end of injection position for autonomous generated
update pulse is depending on calibrated map "IP_EOI_INJ_UPD_PSN_MPI" and it is calculated via "EOI_INJ_UPD_
PSN_MPI".
50.1.10 1.6.5 Ignition-Injection synchronization
One of the most important features of injection realisation is synchronization of ignition and injection control,
in order to maintain consistency of control parameters ? especially in transient situations. Injection pulses shall
be able to be de?ned as "ignition related". Ignition related injection pulses shall be executed in a calibrated
distance to the ignition angle.
Description: If the combustion mode changes it is checked whether an update of the injection and ignition
parameters is possible or not, i.e. it is checked whether the injection or dwell time of the old mode have already
begun or if the injection or dwell time of the new mode should have begun. This is done by comparison of the
injection and ignition phasing already sent to IO-SW and of the new mode relative to the actual engine position
for each cylinder. The ignition and injection parameters are frozen if an update is not possible. Otherwise new
data is sent to IO-SW.
Three main tasks are handled by ignition-injection synchronization :
? Executed of injection pluses and ignition must be belong to the same combustion mode, to ensure that
the combustion mode in any cycle and at any cylinder is consistent;
? Ensure that a consistent set of injection and ignition pulses are applied, as the injection pulses are cou-
pled to the ignition phasing. It is prohibit to use an old injection and new ignition setting or vice verse;
? Ignition-Injection synchronization handles injection mode switches without coupling to ignition (e.g.
switch from high pressure start to single homogeneous injection);

Synchronization of switching between MPI and DI is handled by injection realisation, in order to maintain
consistency of control parameters. In case of change of combustion mode, the desired injection for each

LF_INJ_CMB_CYL_SP: shows which cylinder has ?nished the actual cycle and can be switched.
LF_INJ_CYL_CLC_DI_SWI: is a bitmask which shows the disabled cylinders.
MPI and DI injections have different injection ranges and reference points as described in section "1.5.2 Injection
phasing- general information".

Reference system MPI: reference point 180� before IGN-TDC

50.1.12 1.6.7 Cylinder shut off
The cylinder shut off functionality inhibits the injection on one or more cylinders.
There are two different types of cylinder shut off:
Static cylinder shut off:

off, there is no prede?ned and ?xed association between cylinders and the shut off sequence.
Pattern: is used for fast torque reduction (NR_PAT_SCC) or to avoid fast torque increase (NR_PAT_SEL_CYL)
to improve driveability. It is requested and de?ned in AGGR TQDR. The ?nial request NR_PAT is input for INJR
aggregate.
Main features of dynamic shut off:
- different functions can request a shut off pattern
- the functions have to de?ne which inhibition pattern shall be used
- there is no link between request and the shut off cylinder

50.1.14 1.6.9 Diagnosis
Electrical diagnosis of the power stage and injectors - electrical failures are detected by the injection diagnostic
function, there are different types of diagnosis related to INJR as follow:
Injection valve electrical diagnosis (HPDI):
The HPDI diagnosis evaluates electrical errors which may occur at the injector, the wiring harness to the
injector or their connectors.
Physical errors are detected by the ATIC12x via different HW check routines. For a complete hardware error
detection minimum pulse on (online) and pulse off (of?ine) phases are necessary.
The BSW calls the results of these hardware checks and determinates the corresponding error symptom.
File: 30101R09.00A
12903Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
A valid diagnosis information for each cylinder is delivered at the corresponding INJ-BAS event. The error is
con?rmed after the symptom is debounced via anti-bounce ?lter.
The following injection valve error symptoms can be detected by ATIC 12x IV-diagnosis:
Global symptoms which may lead to limp-home reaction
? OC (open circuit) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off cylinder;
? SCG (short cut to ground) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off power stage;
? SCP (short cut to plus) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off power stage;
? IDT (Indeterminate error = circuit error which can not be determined referring to one of the above symp-
toms) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off power stage
Detailed symptoms which may only occur if the corresponding global error (SCG, SCP) is debounced:
? SCG-H (short cut to ground at high side);
? SCG-L (short cut to ground at low side);
? SCP-H (short cut to plus at high side);
? SCP-L (short cut to plus at low side);
Diagnosis has to be suppressed in case of no valid diagnosis information is available, otherwise the diagnosis
has to be suppressed. This is managed by the calculation of the diagnostic conditions.
Injection valve electrical diagnosis (MPI):
The purpose of the diagnosis is to detect electrical faults for MPI injectors valve as de?ned by OBD I . The
error detection is effected via the ECU hardware.
A valid diagnosis of all failures symptoms can only be detected when the injector was operated at least one
time since the last diagnostic cycle. The error is con?rmed after the symptom is debounced via an anti-bounce
?lter.
The following injection valve error symptoms can be detected by IV-diagnosis:
? OC (open circuit)- recommended limp-home reaction: shut off cylinder;
? SCG (short cut to ground) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off cylinder;
? SCP (short cut to plus) - recommended limp-home reaction: shut off cylinder;
A short circuit to plus (SCP) and an open circuit (OC) can be detected only when the injector is ON. A short
circuit to ground (SCG) can be detected only when the injector is OFF. Otherwise the diagnosis of the symptom
has to be suppressed. This is managed by the calculation of the diagnostic conditions.
HPDI Power stage diagnosis (e.g. ATIC 12x):
The purpose of the injection valve power stage diagnosis is to detect faults of ATIC drivers. The error de-
tection is effected via the ECU hardware and then handled by ASW and forwarded to the error manager.
Recommended limp-home reaction in case of power stage error: shut off power stage bank.
Boost voltage diagnosis:
This diagnosis checks the injector boost voltage regarding reasonable values. The boost voltage is checked
against three limits, C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_1, C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_2 and C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_3.
In order to avoid short-termed variations during injection, VBOOST_MMV is generated. It is the moving mean
value on VBOOST during the last 100ms, measured every 20ms. The boost voltage is continuously moni-
tored.
CSERS_INJ diagnosis:
File: 30101R09.00A
12904Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR General
INJR aggregate supports cold start emission reduction strategy (CSERS) for multiple injection diagnosis. It is
an OBD II diagnosis which runs during catalyst heating at cold start. The diagnosis monitors the phasing,
injection time and the number of injection pulses in multiple injection mode.

� General Information
This module translates all required injection phasing variables and calibration data to the required common
coordinate system. The origin of this common coordinate system is the ignition TDC. Positive values are before
TDC.
The conversion of the phasing values is implemented within the a2l ?le.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: -
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: -
� Function Description
� Signal ?ow diagram:
To unify the coordinate systems for MPI and DI injection, a common coordinate system is de?ned. The trans-
lation of MPI or DI system to the common system can be seen in the schematic below.
All online variables and calibration data with the post?x "_CUS" are displayed in the common injection
coordinate system.
Figure 50.3.1: Common injection coordinate system

50.3.1 Conversion of online variables
Below mentioned output variables shall be de?ned within the a2l ?le. Those variables shall use the same mem-
ory adress as the corresponding input variables but shall be converted to the common coordinate system. The
input variables shall not be removed from the a2l ?le, so that both the new de?ned output variables and input
variables can be accessed from the application system.
Note: No ECU software coding necessary, changes are only done within the a2l ?le for the application sys-
tem.
50.3.1.1 Conversion from SDI coordinate system to common coordinate system:
// SDI coordinate system: 0 ... 720�CRK
// Common coordinate system: -180 ... 540�CRK
SOI_EOI_ACT_SWI_CUS[NC_CYL_NR] = SOI_EOI_ACT_SWI[NC_CYL_NR]
SOI_EOI_ACT_UPD_CUS[NC_CYL_NR] = SOI_EOI_ACT_UPD[NC_CYL_NR]

SOI_MES_CUS[NC_NR_IV_PLS][NC_CYL_NR] = SOI_MES[NC_NR_IV_PLS][NC_CYL_NR]

= ANG_INJ[NC_NR_INJ_CMB][NC_NR_IV_PLS][NC_CYL_NR]

50.3.2 Conversion of calibration data
Below mentioned output variables (calibration data) shall be de?ned within the a2l ?le. Those calibration data
items shall use the same memory adress as the corresponding input variables but shall be converted to the
common coordinate system. The input variables shall be removed from the a2l ?le, so that only the new
de?ned output variables (calibration data) can be accessed from the application system.
Note: No ECU software coding necessary, changes are only done within the a2l ?le for the application sys-
tem.

� General Information
- In this module the signal acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal is described.
- Different model based algorithms (MBA) are developed and applied to determine the closing time tc.
- Simulated MDL?s (MBA) and real measurements show that the closing time tc can be approximately
determined.
In this speci?cation, the following functions are handled:
- Calculation of COSI acquisition parameters
- Window visualization
- Determination of the closing time tc using different algorithms
Note:
COSI controlling and acquisition can be con?gured out via compiler switch NC_COSI_ENA

� General Information
COSI acquisition parameters must be set at reset

50.4.5 ACTION_INJR_CosiAcqDet
This Action determines the closing time of the injector for corresponding cylinder and pulse using different
developed algorithms (MBA) .
The calculation of the algorithms (MBA) MDL_1, MDL_3_2 and MDL_4 are to be brie?y described in this action.
The developed algorithms (MBA) are approaches which create an auxiliary function to calculate the closing
time.
Closing time calculations for MDL_1, and MDL_4 need a ?xed reference time toand a ?xed value yc .
Closing time calculations for MDL_3_2 need only a ?xed value yc .
Robustness check is done for every algorithm as it is necessary to check the plausibility of the closing time.
Determine reference time by bursting the voltage in SW
Choose toas the time where the voltage is close to EOI crosses a ?xed value Vo , this method is done in SW by
bursting the voltage near the EOI.

Figure 50.4.2:
50.4.5.1 Algorithm MDL_1
Algorithm MDL_1 uses the auxiliary function f1,a(t) and determines the closing time as described below.

INJR, Acquisition and interpretation of the injector feedback signal
De?nition: Algorithm MDL_1 is a logarithmic approach which creates an auxiliary function f1,a(t) obtained from
two points. The closing time is to be determined at f1,a(t) = lambda ? (- yc).
50.4.5.2 Algorithm MDL_2, MDL_3_2 and MDL_4
De?nition: Algorithm MDL_2 is a logarithmic approach which creates an auxiliary function f1,b(t) obtained from
V(t) and V?(t). The closing time is to be determined at f1,b(t) = - yc.
The closing time calculation needs a ?xed reference time to and a ?xed value yc .
50.4.5.3 Selection of the ?nal closing time from various MDL?s
The selection of the ?nal closing time (T_COSI_CLOSE_BAS) and the error bit ?eld (LF_COSI_ERR_CLOSE) to
be used by other modules are determined by a calibratable variable C_STATE_COSI_MDL_SEL as described
below.

ACTION_INJR_ClcTiMpiDiMod(IN <PRM_MFF_SP>, OUT <PRM_TI_MPI>) Mode: O
This action calculates and returns the injection time in MPI operation mode from HPDI mass fuel ?ow set point
Parameter Type Hex.Limits Phys.Limits Resol. Unit

� General Information
This module calculates the cylinder individual injection times TI_1_HOM_MPI[x], which are applied at the injec-
tors.
The injection time can be set manually. If the switch LC_TI_1_HOM_MAN_ACT_MPI is set to one, the constant
C_TI_MIN_HOM_MAN_MPI is applied.
In order to avoid linearity problems, the injection time is limited to TI_MIN_MPI. This variable is calculated from
the map IP_TI_MIN_MPI depending on the pressure decrease at the injector PRS_DEC_INJ_1_HOM_MPI. If TI_
MIN_MPI is active it is indicated by the ?ag LV_TI_1_HOM_MIN_MPI = 1.

SEG: LV_ST_END==1

Calculation of fuel density factor:
Fuel density factor is one of the main in?uences on the injection time, this factor is the in?uence of the fuel
type (AFU) and the fuel temperature TFU_INJ via the density of the fuel.
FAC_RHO_INJ = sqrt(density(REF )/density), where density(REF ) is the density at reference-conditions.

Calculations of MFF_STND_REQ_TMP:
This sub module determines the requested standard fuel mass quantity (MFF_STND_REQ_TMP) for a given
cylinder, MFF_STND_REQ_TMP = (MFF_SP from FMSP including multiplicative MFF -correction e.g. from CYBL,
CILC)*(percental factor depending on the number of pulses)*FAC_RHO_INJ. This is shown in the bit ?eld LF_
MFF_STND_MIN_PLS.
A system depending MFF correction is added via MFF_STND_SYS_ADD_COR. This is de?ned in COSI Appl. Inc.
module.
A limitation is done to MFF_STND_MIN_INJ. This is shown in the bit ?eld LF_MFF_STND_MIN_PLS.
Note:
In case of LV_FAC_MFF_TFU_PJR = 1 the density correction is included in FAC_MFF_TFU_PRJ

Calculation of TI_EFF_SP_TMP:
This action calculates the cylinder individual effective injection times TI_EFF_SP_TMP.
According to Bernoulli�s law, TI_EFF_SP_TMP is proportional to MFF_STND_REQ_TMP/ sqrt (PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL)
for high mass fuel ?ows.
In case of TI_EFF maps without COSI:
- A map is used in order to be able to do proper calibrations for small mass fuel ?ows.
In case of "COSI with TI_EFF map":
- In order to consider TFU a 3-dimensional map is used. The ?nal value is the interpolation of the outputs com-
ing from three maps (function of MFF_STND_REQ_TMP and PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) for three temperature values.

INJR, Final injection timing
General Description
Overview
MFF_STND_REQ_TMP de?nition:
MFF_STND_REQ_TMP is in?uenced by alternative fuel and TFU_INJ via the density of the fuel.
=> MFF_STND_REQ_TMP = MFF_HOM_SP * FAC_RHO_INJ * percental factor depending on the number of
pulses.
De?nition: The effective injection time is calculated via TI_EFF(_SP_TMP) = TI + T_CLOSE ? T_OPEN. T_OPEN
is the time between SOI and the opening of the injector. T_CLOSE is the time between EOI and the closing of
the injector. TI is the time between SOI and EOI.

Calculation:
The effective injection time is calculated according to Bernoulli?s law and is proportional to MFF_STND_REQ_
TMP / sqrt (PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) for high mass fuel ?ows and depends on TFU_INJ.
=>TI_EFF_SP_TMP is obtained interpolating the value between three 2-dimensional maps for three reference
temperatures (-20.25 �C, 19.5 �C, 79.5 �C). The inputs of the 2D maps are:
MFF_STND_SYN which is equal to MFF_STND_REQ_TMP and PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL.

INJR, Final injection timing
The output values are interpolated in function of TFU_INJ.
NOTE: TI_EFF_SP_TMP is used in module "COSI control" to proceed TI-calculation.
The main in?uences on the injection time:
- pressure difference between rail pressure and pressure inside the cylinder (PRS_DIF)
- pressure waves
- injector or coil temperature
- details of the pervious injection (PREV_INJ)
- separation time of the last injection (DELTA_PREV)
- current pro?le
- MFF_STND:
- mass fuel ?ow
- density of the fuel
- fuel temperature (TFU_INJ)
- fuel type
SAQ (Set of Additional Quantities) de?nition:
SAQ are the main in?uences on the injection time apart from mass fuel ?ow as described above. Therefore
SAQ is a certain set of those additional quantities.
NOTE: the mass fuel ?ow is not included in the SAQ
the pressure difference between rail pressure and pressure inside the cylinder
(PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) is not usually included in the SAQ, since it is varied as one of the
dimensions of the IP_TI_EFF map.
Reference conditions de?nition:
Calibration and measurements must be done at reference conditions (SAQ = SAQ_ref).
Otherwise inconsistent data which have bad effect on the whole TI calculation and controlling would be the
result..
The basic MFF-characteristics are calibrated via:
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_TEMP_L(MFF_STND_SYN, PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference conditions (SAQ = SAQ_ref), and a tem-
perature of -20.25 �C;
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_TEMP_MID_1(MFF_STND_SYN, PRS_DIF_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference conditions (SAQ = SAQ_ref),
and a temperature of 19.5 �C;
IP_TI_EFF_MFF_TEMP_H(MFF_STND_SYN, PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL) at reference conditions (SAQ = SAQ_ref), and a
temperature of 79.5 �C;
.
NOTE: - TI_EFF_SP_TMP is used in module "COSI control" to proceed TI-calculation.

50.7.8.1 Get number of actual and previous cylinder at INJBAS event
At INJBAS event, the logical number of the actual cylinder (Cyl_av) is delivered from the I/O SW and assigned

50.7.21 Crash Signal Reaction of Injection Driver
� General Information
This chapter describes the behavior of the injection driver during vehicle crash. Under crash conditions, all
selected injectors (LF_IV_CRASH_PAT) are open for a prede?ned period (TI_CRASH), to drain off the fuel from
the rail into the cylinder. This will reduce the danger of ?re or explosion, if the rail will be damaged.
De?nition of STATE_INJ_CRASH_ACT:
0H = no request received;
The injection driver works under normal conditions.
1H = vehicle crash reaction request received by LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 1;
The injection driver will be shut down.
2H = injection driver crash reaction acknowledged;
The selected injectors are opened for TI_CRASH period.
3H = injection driver crash reaction ?nished;
All working injectors are closed. The driver is under hold conditions.
De?nition of NC_INJ_CRASH_VAR_ACT:
0 = No injection reaction for crash;
1 = Injection restart is possible immediately after ?nished crash reaction (if activated) and
LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0;
2 = Injection restart is possible after IGK off=>on after ?nished crash reaction (if activated)
and LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0;
3 = Injection restart is possible after reset and LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0;
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At reset:
T_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0
if LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 1
then
STATE_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 3H
else
STATE_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0H
endif
At igk off => on:
#if(2) NC_INJ_CRASH_VAR_ACT = 2
if STATE_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 3H and LV_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0
then
STATE_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0H
T_INJ_CRASH_ACT = 0
else
do nothing
endif
#endif(2)
Activation: Always
Deactivation: Not active

50.7.22 Time Synchronous Tasks (1s)
� General Information
This chapter describes time synchronous tasks with the recurrence of 1 second.
Here, the voltage setpoint for the DCDC converter is set depending on the temperature of the ECU. The DCDC
voltage is transferred via PWM value.
The measured voltage NC_V_ADC_REF_INJ is more accurate then the ADC reference voltage. By calculating a
correction factor for all ADC measurement values, this accuracy can be transferred to all ADC measurements.
This feature exists only for certain injection hardware drivers.
Voltage reference calibration is activated by LC_V_ADC_REF_ENA switch and a positive plausibility check of the
raw value.
� Application Conditions
Activation: Always
Deactivation: Not active
Recurrence: 1 s

50.7.24 Function function_mpi_update
� General Information
50.7.25 Make- up pulse for HPDI
� General Information
A make-up pulse is an additional injection pulse delivered after the standard pulse in single injection mode. It
can be executed in case that an increase of fuel mass is requested for the actual cycle, but cannot be realized
by the standard pulse as the update is coming too late.
Conditions for Make-up pulse execution:
? the injection time of the Make up pulse (additional pulse) must be bigger than the calibration map "IP_
TI_ADD_PLS_MIN_4"
? Make up pulse is available only for single injection mode
For injection time duration of a Make pulse a multiplicative factor FAC_INJ_ADD_PLS can be used. This factor
depends on the calibration map IP_FAC_ADD_PLS, which can be used to shorten the duration of an additive
pulse at higher speed (0 ms at very high speed).
Standard calibration for IP_FAC_ADD_PLS is 1 for all cells.
Example:
In the following example several cases are mentioned to describe how make-up pulse or enlargement of the
standard pulse is realized. The update scenario depends on the update limit (determined by combustion
mode) and the time when it is requested.

Case 2: A standard pulse of duration 2ms is executed as required at segment 1. Enlargement of the standard

not yet elapsed as shown in the ?gure "Case 2".Make up pulse is not possible at segment 3 as the update limit

Case 3: A standard pulse of duration 2ms is executed as required at segment 1. Make up pulse is possible as
required at segment 2 (0.5 * FAC_INJ_ADD_PLS "see TI of make up pulse calculation below") as the update limit
has not yet elapsed. Enlargement of Make up pulse is not possible as required at segment 3 as update limit
was already in the past.
Case 4: A standard pulse of duration 2ms is executed as required at segment 1. Make up pulse is possible as
required at segment 2 (0.5 * FAC_INJ_ADD_PLS "see TI of make up pulse calculation below") as the update limit
has not yet elapsed. Enlargement of Make up pulse is also possible at required segment 3 (TI at segment 3 - TI
at segment 2 = 0.3 ms) as update limit is still in the future.
TI of make-up pulse calculation for case 3 and 4 are done as follow:
TI of the make-up pulse = (TI at segment 2 - TI at segment 1 = 0.5)* FAC_INJ_ADD_PLS
As mentioned, for execution of TI of the make up pulse must be bigger than IP_TI_ADD_PLS_MIN_4.

� General Information
The aim is to presynchronise and start the engine as fast as possible. The experience has shown, that when the
engines was switched off, it will stop in the most of the cases at the same speci?c positions. This information
can be used together with the information of relative engine positions PSN_ENG_SYN_MIN and PSN_ENG_SYN_
MAX to presynchronise the engine. In the case that the difference of PSN_ENG_SYN_MIN and PSN_ENG_SYN_
MAX is lower than the threshold PSN_DIF_ENG_SYN_THD than the probability to put the pre injection on the
valid cylinder with a good phasing is 100%. The pre injection shall carried out with the latest possible CRK
angle for the pre injection, PSN_ENG_SYN_MAX. Due to the fact, that PSN_ENG_SYN_MAX is nearly ?x and PSN_
ENG_SYN_MIN change from tooth to tooth and in addition to that the EOI phasing calculation is done with
PSN_ENG_SYN_MIN, the ?rst pre injection angle has to be corrected by PSN_DIF_ENG_SYN.
The angle ANG_ENG_SYN_DLY describes beside the GAP (see case 1) and the CAM (see case 2) event a third
event (see case 3). In the case that the running engine turns already ANG_ENG_SYN_DLY and no CAM or GAP
event occur, then the variable PSN_ENG_SYN_MAX will set to the next possible CAM or GAP position. The angle
ANG_ENG_SYN_DLY is de?ned in the aggregate ENSD.

50.8.2.1 Enable Pre injection
Several conditions have to be ful?lled in order to permit a preinjection. In the case, that a preinjection shall be
carried out, the state variable STATE_ST_PRE = NC_ST_ENA_PRE_INJ, otherwise the standard injection with the
injection time TI_x is applied synchronously and STATE_ST_PRE = NC_ST_ENA_SYN_INJ.
The preinjection will be carried out at the moment when PSN_DIF_ENG_SYN the difference between PSN_ENG_
SYN_MAX and PSN_ENG_SYN_MIN is lower than the threshold PSN_DIF_ENG_SYN_THD. This event is indicated
by setting the bit NC_ST_ACT_PRE_INJ. The function is activated at the moment when the ?rst valid tooth was
passed and the pre injection variables were con?gured.

INJR, Injection phase
ACTION_INJR_PHASE() Mode: O
This action calculates injection phasing according to phasing set point strategy
� Import actions:
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(INOUT <PRM_LF [NC_NR_BYTE_INJ]>, IN <PRM_IDX_BIT>, IN <Prm_Bit>)
ACTION_INJR_ShoTDeltaInj(IN <PRM_Cmb>, IN <PRM_PLS>, IN <PRM_CYL>, IN <PRM_T_Delta_Short>)
� General Information
Note: For speci?cation clarity the dimension NC_NR_INJ_CMB has been ignored through the whole speci?ca-
tion since cmb= IDX_INJ_CMB is always constant and equal to 0.
Note: The display of arrays depending on NC_NR_INJ_CMB must be done as speci?ed in the de?nition of the
NC?s, depending on NC_NR_IV_PLS is PLS_1/2.., see de?nition of the NC?s.
The injection phasing functionality calculates and manages the position where an injection pulse is placed.
The realization of these features are neatly connected with the multi pulse concept.
All calculations within formula section are valid in a physical meaning!
This function calculates the collision handling for injection pulses. As long as there is no violation of applied
boundaries and no collision of pulses, the applied injection phasing ANG_INJ_SP is copied to ANG_INJ.
The functionality works in following order:
1. Determine max-crk-range
2. Determine total sum of TI + T_DELTA, left or right corner of Inj-Crank-Window and Prio-pulse.
3. Check if pulse-separation-times can be made smaller such that the resulting total sum of TI + T_DELTA is
equal to max-crk-range.
4. A hysteresis function is applied to avoid toggling of violation of the maximum injection range.
5. Set position of allowed Inj-Crank-window.
6. Go through pulse sequence from the left to the right and do necessary pulse shifts.
The fuel can be injected over a range of 720 �CRK. The cylinder individual zero position of this range is
de?ned via the constants NC_CRK_INJ_REF_TDC and NC_CRK_INJ_BAS_REF with reference to the ignition TDC
of cylinder 0, see ?gure below.

Each cylinder has its own 720�CRK injection axis. The reference point of each axis is related to the ?ring top
centre of the logical cylinder 0 by means of CRK_INJ_BAS[x]:
Limitation of the injection phasing range for HPDI is calibrated via SOI_LIM_INJ and EOI_LIM_INJ_CYL.
Pulse collision management
Injection pulse prioritization : Pulse prioritization is de?ned to avoid pulse collision on a cylinder. For each
combustion mode, one pulse is de?ned as the priority pulse.
In case of pulse collision, the high priority pulse remains and the other pulses will be shifted. Typically only the
?rst or the last pulse can be a high priority pulse.
Continuous line function: should indicate when the possible injection range is totally used. At violation of the
maximum injection range, the gaps between the pulses will be reduced to ?t the maximum injection range. A
hysteresis function could be applied.

Figure 50.10.2: Gap reduction example
Pulse collision management has to ensure that the following restrictions are not violated:
1. No pulse must be performed beyond the injection range limits "SOI_LIM_INJ" and "EOI_LIM_INJ_CYL".
2. A calibrated minimum time ?C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" must be available between two consecutive pulses.
3. Any violation leads to a shifting or cutting of pulses, in accordance to the following priorities:
4.
a) Priority 0: the number of pulses has to be executed as requested;
b) Priority1: the correct fuel mass (injection time) of the injection pulses shall have higher priority than
the calibrated pulse phasing;
c) Priority 2: phasing of the high priority pulse has to be maintained;
d) Priority 3: phasing of low pulses has to be maintained;
This is ensured by the following pulse collision management algorithm:
1. In case SOI of ?rst pulse is earlier than SOI_LIM, this pulse will be shifted later so that SOI = SOI_LIM. In
case that an overlap with subsequent pulses will result due this shift, these pulses would be shifted later,
from left to right ? until the minimum distance "C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" is reached everywhere.
2. In case EOI of last pulse is later than EOI_LIM, this pulse will be shifted earlier so that EOI = EOI_LIM. In
case that an overlap with preceding pulses will result due this shift, these pulses would be shifted earlier,
from right to left ? until the minimum distance "C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4" is reached everywhere.
3. If the sum of all TI + minimum delay time is bigger than the distance EOI_LIM ? SOI_LIM (maximum
injection range completely ?lled) the last pulse is cut.
4. In case of overlapping pulses ( = distance is smaller than C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4), they are shifted away
from the high priority pulse. A high priority pulse is always the ?rst or the last one, and it will keep its
position during shifting. Shifting will begin with the nearest neighbor, then next one and so on, until the
minimum distance C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4 is maintained everywhere.
Important points must be taken into consideration:
? If the ?rst pulse is already at SOI_LIM, shifting will go from left to right ? even if the last pulse would be
high priority (see point 1 above);
? If the last pulse is already at EOI_LIM, shifting will go from right to left ? even if the ?rst pulse would be
high priority (see point 2 above);
A calibratable hysteresis function is implemented to set or reset (separate) the continuous function for HPDI
system even if the maximum injection range is not completely used, as the behavior of the combustion engine
get worse and torque reduction is requested. Therefore the calibration thresholds "C_CRK_IINJ_RNG_HYS_
LIM_BOL" and "C_CRK_IINJ_RNG_HYS_LIM_TOL" are de?ned as a minimum and a maximum distance to the
maximum injection range (SOI_LIM_INJ_CYL - EOI_LIM_INJ_CYL) to set and reset a bit?eld ?LF_INJ_RNG_SHO_

50.11.2.1.1 Calculation of injection ranges and continuous line functionality
Continuous line functionality should indicate when the possible injection range is totally used. There are two
limiting injection ranges. One range is an electrical limit which is formed out of NC_CRK_INJ_RNG and the gap
which is occupied by io-software and hardware (SOC_INJ_SOI_GAP). The other limit is the physical limit which
is given by application data (SOI_LIM EOI_LIM_HOM SOC_INJ_SOI_GAP). The minimum of these ranges is
used to compare whether the limit is reached or not. A hysteresis function could be applied.

� General Information
In this speci?cation the following functions are described:
- determination of CAM phases shifts of inlet and outlet which are used for injection phasing set points calcu-
lation.
- calculation of the injection phasing set points and pulse separation times for the different combustion
modes in dependence on the engine operating state.
- limitation of the injection phasing range.
- the limitation of the injection due to the injection range violation for MPI-HPDI systems.
- the overall injection range violation "LV_CRK_DIF_SOI_EOI_LIM", i.e. difference between SOI and EOI is
beyond the maximum for MPI-DI system, therefore the pulse will be limited through TQDR aggregate.
- calculation of the aggregate interface variable "CRK_DIF_SOI_IGN" to LACO aggregate.
The injection phasing set point is calculated for dual injection systems (MPI and HPDI) depends on the engine
operating state, which can be changed easily according to the engine needs.

INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
The fuel can be injected over a range of 720 �CRK. The cylinder individual zero position of this range is de-
?ned via the constants NC_CRK_INJ_REF_TDC and NC_CRK_INJ_BAS_REF with reference to the ignition TDC of
cylinder 0, as described below.
The position of the injection event within the engine working cycle is a function of the engine operating state.
The desired phasing is limited to the physically possible range. The range is related to the ?ring top dead
center by an con?gurable offset.

50.12.2.1.2 Limitation of the injection phasing range for MPI and HPDI systems
50.12.2.1.2.1 Limitation of the injection phasing range for HPDI system
In this section the limitation of start of injection angle "SOI_LIM_INJ" and end of injection angle "EOI_LIM_INJ_
CYL" for HPDI system are calculated.
The earliest possible start of the injection angle is determined by the minimum between the con?gurable
constant NC_SOI_LIM_TOL and the total value between the shift of the exhaust camshaft position and the
calibration map IP_SOI_MAX.
The limitation of latest possible end of injection of the direct injection system is depending on the number of
the injected pulses via "NR_INJ_PLS_HPDI_STND" as discussed in the next section.

50.12.2.1.2.1.1 Injection phase limitation of single injection pulse for HPDI
It is possible to calibrate the injection phase limitation of a single injected pulse during start mode different to
the injection phase in out of start mode.
At start the latest possible angle is determined by the calibration C_EOI_MIN_HOM_ST and added to fuel pres-
sure correction calibration map IP_EOI_MIN_HOM_FUP_COR.
At out of start the latest possible angle is determined by the calibration C_EOI_MIN_HOM and added to fuel
pressure correction calibration map IP_EOI_MIN_HOM_FUP_COR.

It is possible to calibrate the injection phase limitation during start different to the injection phase in the area
out of start.

MPI.
The earliest possible start of injection angle is determined by the calibration C_SOI_MAX_MPI.

In this section, the determination of the injection angles and pulse separation times for both HPDI and MPI
systems are calculated for the different combustion modes.
The activation of injection system MPI is indicated via "NC_IDX_INJ_MPI_ENA".
The activation of injection system HPDI is indicated via "NC_IDX_INJ_HPDI_ENA".
The injection pulse information for each combustion mode is indicated via CMBD-bits in the logical ?eld "LF_
INJ_CMB_SP".
The activation of the injection phasing at Start and Out of start depends on index bit "NC_IDX_INJ_ST_ENA"
in logical ?eld "LF_INJ_CMB_SP". If this bit index is enabled then activate injection phasing at Start, otherwise
activate injection phasing at out of Start:
Injection phasing at start
NC_IDX_INJ_STST_ENA: Stop-Start mode
NC_IDX_INJ_ST_H_PRS_ENA: High pressure start mode, otherwise low pressure start mode
Injection phasing at out of start:
NC_IDX_INJ_CH_ENA: catalyst heating mode, otherwise operating point mode
NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_HPDI_ENA : HPDI retarded pulse is enable
NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_MPI_ENA : MPI retarded pulse is enable

via bit index "NC_IDX_INJ_ST_ENA" in ?eld "LF_INJ_CMB_SP", otherwise clear special phasing request for next
STST cycle is enabled which it consists of two mode:
high pressure start mode and low pressure start mode.

50.12.2.1.3.1.1.5 Calculate cylinder individual engine position
Calculate the cylinder individual engine position for injection phasing calculation via ACTION_INJR_GetCrkP-
snCyl and check for special phasing window that indicates that the cylinder is injectable in a certain range.
Bit i of LF_INJ_POS_ENG_SOI = 0 engine position is outside special phasing ->normal phasing is applied
Bit i of LF_INJ_POS_ENG_SOI = 1 engine position is inside special phasing window ->special phasing is
applied

INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
50.12.2.1.3.1.1.8 Calculation of injection angles and separation times for Stop-Start mode
Finial calculations of the injection angles and separation times for Stop-Start mode are done for special and
normal phasing for HPDI system in dependence on the injection modes for combustion state set points .
Enabling of special or normal phasing is done via "LF_INJ_PHA_STST" for the requested cylinder.
For HPDI, the third pulse is the high priority pulse.
For MPI, passive phasing, when MPI is not active, depends on calibration "C_EOI_MPI_PAS".

Enabling of special or normal phasing is done via "LF_INJ_PHA_STST" for the requested cylinder.
For HPDI, the third pulse is the high priority pulse.
For MPI, passive phasing, when MPI is not active, depends on calibration "C_EOI_MPI_PAS".

INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
50.12.2.1.3.1.1.8.1 Apply special phasing for HPDI injection system
In this section, the special phasing for HPDI system is applied and the ?nial calculation of the injection angles
and separation times for Stop-Start mode are done in dependence on the injection modes for combustion
state set points.
Enabling of ignition coupling of the last injection pulse is indicated via "NC_IDX_INJ_MOD_IGN_ENA". A copy of
ignition angle is added to the high priority injection angle (third pulse) to ensure a consistent ignition- injection
dataset.

50.12.2.1.3.1.2 Clear special phasing request for next STST cycle
At start, the clear special phasing request for next STST cycle is activated if Stop-Start mode is disabled via bit
index "NC_IDX_INJ_ST_ENA" in "LF_INJ_CMB_SP".
Clear special phasing request for the next Stop-Start cycle consists of two modes :
High pressure start mode is activated via index bit "NC_IDX_INJ_ST_H_PRS_ENA" in "LF_INJ_CMB_SP", otherwise
low pressure start mode is activated.
High pressure start ->Call subroutine CLC_ST_H_PRS: (cmb-modes ST_H_xxx)
Low pressure start ->Call subroutine CLC_ST_L_PRS: (cmb-mode ST_L_xxx)

50.12.2.1.3.1.2.1 Subroutine CLC_ST_H_PRS: (cmb-modes ST_H_xxx)
High pressure start mode ->Call subroutine CLC_STST: (cmb-modes STST_xxx)
This subroutine determines the injection angles set points and pulse separation times for both HPDI and MPI
systems of the high pressure mode at start.
Note: No retarded pulse update during high pressure start mode.

INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
Calculations of injection mode dependent angles and times depend on the injection modes for combustion
state set points the following CBMD-bits are used for high pressure start mode:
Switch cases:
CASE 25 = CASE NC_IDX_ST_H_1_S =>Single HPDI pulse
CASE 26 = CASE NC_IDX_ST_H_2_S =>Double HPDI pulses
CASE 27 = CASE NC_IDX_ST_H_3_S =>Triple HPDI pulses (?rst pulse de?ned via delta time to the second
pulse)
CASE 28 = CASE NC_IDX_ST_H_3_S_2 =>Triple HPDI pulses (?rst pulse de?ned via SOI)
CASE 29 = CASE NC_IDX_ST_H_4_MPI_S_2 =>MPI and triple HPDI pulses (?rst pulse is de?ned via SOI)

INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
"NC_IDX_INJ_ST_ENA" in LF_INJ_CMB_SP[NC_NR_INJ_CMB].
Clear special phasing request for next STST cycle.
At out of start, enabling of the injection phasing at catalyst heating mode is activated if index bit
"NC_IDX_INJ_CH_ENA" in LF_INJ_CMB_SP[NC_NR_INJ_CMB] is enabled, otherwise operating point mode is en-
abled.
"Add retarded pulse" for HPDI is activated if Index of bit "NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_HPDI_ENA". in LF_INJ_CMB_
SP[NC_NR_INJ_CMB] is enabled.
"Add retarded pulse" for MPI is activated if Index of bit "NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_MPI_ENA". in LF_INJ_CMB_SP[NC_
NR_INJ_CMB] is enabled.
Catalyst heating ->Call subroutine CLC_TEG_CH (cmb-modes CH_xxx)
Operating point ->Call subroutine CLC_TQ_OPP (cmb-modes OPP_xxx)
Check retarded pulse update for second pulse HPDI ->Call subroutine ADD_RTD_PLS_UPD_HPDI
Check retarded pulse update for second pulse MPI ->Call subroutine ADD_RTD_PLS_UPD_MPI

50.12.2.1.3.2.1.1 Switch cases injection mode dependent angles and times depend on the injection modes
for combustion state set points for catalyst heating mode calculation
Calculations of injection mode dependent angles set points and times depend on the injection modes for
combustion state set points the following CBMD-bits are used for catalyst heating mode at out of start :
Switch cases:
CASE 14 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_1 =>Single HPDI pulse
CASE 15 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_2 =>Double HPDI pulses (HOM/HOM)
CASE 16 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_2_S_1 =>MPI plus double HPDI pulses (HOM/S)
CASE 17 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_3_S_2 =>Triple HPDI triple pulses (HOM/S/S)
CASE 18 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_MPI_1 =>Only MPI pulse
CASE 19 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_MPI_2_S =>MPI plus Single HPDI pulses (S)
CASE 20 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_SA_2_S_1 =>Double HPDI pulses for sec. air (HOM/S)
CASE 21 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_SA_3_S_1 =>Triple HPDI pulses for sec. air (HOM/S/S)
CASE 22 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2 =>MPI plus single HPDI pulses for sec. air (HOM)
CASE 23 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2_S_1 =>MPI plus double HPDI pulses for sec. air (S)
CASE 24 = CASE NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_3_S_1 =>MPI plus double HPDI pulses for sec. air (HOM/S)

50.12.2.1.3.2.1.2 Finial calculations of the injection angles and separation time for catalyst heating mode
In this section, ?nial calculations of the injection angles set points and separation times for catalyst heat-
ing mode after start are done for MPI and HPDI systems in dependence of the injection modes for combustion
state set points .
For MPI, active phasing is calculated which is indicated via "lv_mpi_tmp", otherwise passive phasing is calculat-
ing depends on calibration "C_EOI_MPI_PAS".
For HPDI, the injection angles and separation times are calculated as described in the next sections.

50.12.2.1.3.2.1.2.1 Calculation of the ?rst pulse for HPDI for catalyst heating mode
In this section, the injection phasing set points and the separation times of the ?rst HPDI pulse are calculated.
In case of enabling CMBD bit "NC_IDX_CH_MPI_2_S" there is no ?rst injection pulse, otherwise in case of enabling
one of the following CMBD bit (NC_IDC_CH_1, NC_IDX_CH_2 and NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2) the ?rst pulse is always
de?ned via SOI.
In case of CMBD bit NC_IDC_CH_1 or NC_IDX_CH_2 or NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2 the pulse separation time"T_
DELTA_INJ_4" is set to 0 , otherwise it is set to the calibration "C_DELTA_T_MIN_DUI_4.

50.12.2.1.3.2.1.2.3 Calculation of the third pulse for HPDI for catalyst heating mode
In this section, the injection phasing and the separation time of the third HPDI pulse are calculated.
At catalyst heating mode the third pulse is always de?ned via EOI, therefore the pulse separation time is set to
0.
The injection phasing set point (ANG_INJ_SP) for the third pulse for the different CMBD bits of the catalyst
heating mode is calculated as shown in the following ?gure.
Enabling of ignition coupling of the last injection pulse is indicated via "NC_IDX_INJ_MOD_IGN_ENA". A copy of
ignition angle is added to the third injection angle to ensure a consistent ignition- injection dataset, otherwise
the absolute angle of the third pulse is calculated.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2 Subroutine CLC_TQ_OPP: (cmb-mode TQ_OPP_1/2/3)
Operating point mode at out of start ->Call subroutine CLC_TQ_OPP: (cmb-mode TQ_OPP_1/2/3)
At out of start, the operating point mode is activated if catalyst heating mode is disabled via bit index "NC_IDX_
INJ_CH_ENA" in "LF_INJ_CMB_SP",
This subroutine calculates:
- Ratio of cold after start phasing during warm up depending on injection mode (MPI and HPDI).

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.1 Calculation of RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST depending on injection mode (MPI or HPDI)
RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST is calculated depending on operation mode: MPI or HPDI or MPI&HPDI.

For MPI ratio
calculation IP_RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST_MPI map is used, for HPDI mode =>IP_RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST. In case of
MPI&HPDI mode the coldest RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST(max-choice) from MPI and HPDI is taken.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.2.1 Pull fuel cut off
The fading factor "RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC" is calculated between warm and cold phasing during post PUC phase."LV_
INJ_PUC_TMP" indicates enabling of pull cut off, otherwise disabling of pull cut off.
In case of presence of pull cut off ,the fading factor "RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC" is determined depending on calibra-
tion map "IP_RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC" and the ratio of cold after start phasing during warm up "RATIO_ANG_INJ_
CAST".

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.2.2 Initialize hold and ramp counter
Initialize hold and ramp counter in case "LV_INJ_PUC_TMP" state changes from 1 ->0 depending on the follow-
ing calibration maps "IP_NR_CYC_ANG_INJ_HLD_PUC" and "IP_NR_CYC_ANG_INJ_RAMP_PUC".
In case the ramp counter "CTR_SEG_INJ_RAM_PUC" is greater than 0 means ramp phase and decrement ratio
"RATIO_ANG_INJ_DEC_PUC" is calculated , otherwise no ramp phase and set decrement ratio RATIO_ANG_INJ_
DEC_PUC" to the maximum value.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.2.3 Hold and ramp phase after PUC or in PUC phase
In case the hold counter "CTR_SEG_INJ_HLD_PUC" is greater than 0 or PUC is enabled via
"LV_INJ_PUC_TMP" then hold phase after PUC or in PUC phase and RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC shall not be changed,
otherwise in case ramp counter "CTR_SEG_INJ_RAMP_PUC" is greater than 0 and the ratio of cold start phas-
ing during post phase PUC phase "RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC" is greater than ratio of cold start phasing dur-
ing warm "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST" then ramp phase after PUC.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.3 Recalculate ?nal fading factor
The ratio of cold after start phasing during warm up RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST is calculated for the maximum
value between "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST" and "RATIO_ANG_INJ_PUC".
At warm phasing, the oil temperature should be considered via calibration map "IP_RATIO_ANG_INJ_OPP".
The fading factor "RATIO_ANG_INJ_OPP" is set to 1 for oil temperature phasing during warm phasing, otherwise
set to 0 for standard warm phasing.
The ?nial fading factors RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST" and "RATIO_ANG_INJ_OPP" are used for the calculation of in-
jection angles set points for HPDI and MPI depend on the injection modes for combustion state set points of
operating point mode.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.4 Switch cases for injection mode dependent angles and times for HPDI depend on the in-
jection modes for combustion state set points for operating point mode
Calculation of injection mode dependent angles setpoints and times for HPDI depend on the injection modes
for combustion state set points, the following CBMD-bits are used for operating point mode at out of start :
Switch cases:
CASE 0 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_1 =>DI single injection (HOM)
CASE 1 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_2 =>DI double injection (HOM/HOM)
CASE 2 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_2_S_1 =>DI double injection (HOM/S)
CASE 3= CASE NC_IDX_OPP_3_HOMS_S =>DI triple injection (HOM/HOMS/S)
CASE 4 = CASENC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_1 =>DI single injection (HOM) for scavenging
CASE 5= CASE NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_2 =>DI double injection (HOM/HOM) for scavenging
CASE 6 = CASE NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_2_S_1 =>DI double injection (HOM/S) for scavenging
CASE 7 = CASE NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_3_HOMS_S =>DI triple injection (HOM/HOMS/S) for scavenging
CASE 8 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_1 =>only MPI pulse
CASE 9 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_2 =>MPI plus DI single injection pulse (MPI/HOM)
CASE 10 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_2_S =>MPI plus DI single injection pulse (MPI/S)
CASE 11 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_3 =>MPI plus DI double injection pulse (MPI/HOM/HOM)
CASE 12 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_3_S_1 =>MPI plus DI double injection pulse (MPI/HOM/S)
CASE 13 = CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_4_S_2 =>MPI plus DI triple injection pulse (MPI/HOM/S/S)
CASE 38 = CASE NC_IDX_RAMP_MPL_TRAN =>MPI plus DI single injection pulse (MPI/HOM) - special
transition mode

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.4.1 CASE NC_IDX_OPP_2 and NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_2 for operating point mode
Double HPDI pulses are enabled in case NC_IDX_OPP_2 and NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_2 based on the following ho-
mogenous injection pulses.
- ?rst pulse is de?ned via SOI (high prio pulse).
- second pulse is de?ned via delta time to the ?rst pulse (T_TI).
The calculation of injection phasing for the double HPDI injection pulses is depending on the fading factors for
cold and warm phasing via variables "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST" and "RATIO_ANG_INJ_OPP".

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.4.4 CASE NC_IDX_OPP_3_HOMS_S and NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_3_HOMS_S for operating point mode
Triple HPDI pulses are enabled in case NC_IDX_OPP_3_HOMS_S and NC_IDX_SCAV_OPP_3_HOMS_S based on
the following (HOM/HOMS/S) injection pulses.
First pulse is de?ned via SOI.
- Second pulse is de?ned via delta time to the third pulse (TI_T).
- Third pulse is de?ned via EOI (high prio pulse).
The calculation of injection phasing for the triple HPDI injection pulses is depending on the fading factors for
cold and warm phasing via variables "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST" and "RATIO_ANG_INJ_OPP".

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.4.8 CASE NC_IDX_OPP_MPI_3 for operating point mode

injection pulses:
- ?rst pulse is de?ned via SOI (high prio pulse).
- second pulse is de?ned via delta time to the ?rst pulse (T_TI).

tween cold and warm phasing via variable "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST".
Note: the injection mode dependent angles for MPI are calculated in section "Injection mode dependent angles
for MPI calculation", in this section only the calculation for HPDI is done.

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.5 Injection mode dependent angles for MPI calculation
Calculations of injection mode dependent angles for MPI depend on the injection modes of the different
CMBD-bits (as described at section "Switch cases for injection angles and times calculation of HPDI for operat-
ing point mode").
The activation of injection system MPI is indicated via "NC_IDX_INJ_MPI_ENA". Passive phasing, when MPI is not
