INJR, Injection phase (Appl. Inc.)
The calculation of injection phasing for MPI depends on the following factors:
- fading factor between cold or warm phase via variable "RATIO_ANG_INJ_CAST".
- dynamic injection phasing for positive and negative load jump for MPI mode (described in the next
section).
- shift of the exhaust or inlet camshaft relative to passive position for MPI phasing.
- correction during after start for MPI injections via "IP_ANG_INJ_OFS_REST_MPI" and the number of segment
after PUC to apply MPI injection phase via calibration constant "C_CYC_INJ_OFS_REST".

50.12.2.1.3.2.2.5.1 Dynamic injection phasing for MPI
In this section, the dynamic injection phasing for positive and negative load jump for MPI mode is introduced.

Load jump for MPI is detected if the minimum of the manifold air pressure set point and measured pressure
upstream throttle difference to the measured manifold pressure exceed the upper and lower limits which is
de?ned via C_MAP_DELTA_ANG_MPI_SWI_MAX and C_MAP_DELTA_ANG_MPI_SWI_MIN.
Positive load for dynamic injection phasing is calculated if it exceeds the upper limits C_MAP_DELTA_ANG_MPI_
SWI_MAX via IP_EOI_BAS_MPI_OPP_CAST_DYN.
Negative load for dynamic injection phasing is calculated if it is less than the lower limits C_MAP_DELTA_ANG_
MPI_SWI_MIN via IP_EOI_BAS_MPI_OPP_CAST_DYN_NEG.
Otherwise the normal injection phasing is calculated via IP_EOI_BAS_MPI_OPP_CAST.

50.12.2.1.4 Subroutine OVW_ManualPha: (all)
This subroutine enables the manual overwrite phasing and timing for HPDI depending on the input parameter
as follow:
- Manual overwrite timing for HPDI ->Call subroutine OVW_ManualPha(1)
- Manual overwrite phasing for HPDI ->Call subroutine OVW_ManualPha(0)
The activation of this subroutine depends on the following calibration ?elds:
- CLF_ANG_INJ_SP_MAN_ACT ->activate the manual overwrite phasing for HPDI
- CLF_T_DELTA_INJ_MAN_ACT ->activate the manual overwrite timing for HPDI

50.12.2.2 Project speci?c calculations after core calculation of phasing
In this section, the following calculations are done:
- the project speci?c calculation is done after the core calculation of module "Injection phasing"
- the limitation of the injection due to the injection range violation for MPI-HPDI systems
"LV_CRK_INJ_RNG_LIM"
- the overall injection range violation "LV_CRK_DIF_SOI_EOI_LIM", i.e. difference between SOI and EOI is
beyond the maximum for MPI-DI system, therefore the pulse will be limited through TQDR aggregate.
- calculation of the aggregate interface variable "CRK_DIF_SOI_IGN" to LACO aggregate

INJR, Injector current control
50.13.2.1 Injection Current Switch
Injector current pro?le switch is con?gurable inside via NC_CUR_VAR_IV the AGGR. At start of the engine de-
pending on TCO_ST, Injector current pro?le is clamped to high current pro?le to warm up all electrical injection
components as fast as possible. Afterwards two criterias keep the current pro?le in low mode. Fuel Pressure
(FUP) and the maximum time of all injection pulses (TI). If one of this criterias is violated the current pro?le is
switched to high current pro?le. Afterwards one pressure criterium switchs the current pro?le in overpressure
mode.
Figure 50.13.1:
#IF (NC_CUR_VAR_IV == 1)
#THEN /*Injector Current Switch*/
(A) IF (LC_CUR_VAR_IV AND
(
(T_AST >= IP_CUR_VAR_ACT_T_AST (TCO_ST)) OR
(NR_INJ_PLS_HPDI_STND > 1)
)
)
(A) THEN / * high pressure current profile or low pressure current profile
or overpressure current profile can be applied */
(B) IF (FUP_H_INJ[0] < C_FUP_H_CUR_OVER_PRS_IV_DEAC) /* FUP Criteria
for overpressure current profile switch */
(B) THEN
LV_FUP_OVER_PRS_TMP = 0
(B) ELSE
(B1) IF (FUP_H_INJ[0] > C_FUP_H_CUR_OVER_PRS_IV_ACT
(B1) THEN
LV_FUP_OVER_PRS_TMP = 1
(B1) ELSE
/* do nothing */
(B1) ENDIF
(B) ENDIF
(C) IF (FUP_H_INJ[0] < C_FUP_H_CUR_L_IV) /* FUP Criteria for

(C) THEN

(C) ELSE
(D) IF (FUP_H_INJ[0] > C_FUP_H_CUR_H_IV
(D) THEN
LV_FUP_H_TMP = 1
(D) ELSE
/* do nothing */
(D) ENDIF
(C) ENDIF
/* Combination of the FUP criteria?s to switch between high and low current
profile and switch to the overpressure current profile */
(E) IF LV_FUP_OVER_PRS_TMP = 1

(E) ELSE

(F) ENDIF

#IF NLF_INJ_CUS_FCT_ACT[bit 0] == 1

50.13.2.4 Calculation of con?guration parameters for ATIC 124 or ATIC 121
Below parameters are defined for ATIC124:
CUR_IV_PEAK_THD_FB - Peak current threshold level for "Injector Current
Feedback"(PK_DETECT_CUR)
T_IV_PEAK_DET - Peak detection under-time (PK_DETECT_TIME)
T_OUT_IV_DIAG_DET - Offline diagnosis detection time-out (OFFL_TO)
T_DLY_IV_DIAG_ST - Offline diagnosis start delay (INJ_IDLE_TO)

#ELSE /*Injector specific values are configurated - application values not

INJR, Injection pressure correction
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
Enable manual injection counter-pressure (used for prs_dif - calculation)
� Action De?nitions
ACTION_INJR_PrsCor() Mode: O
This action calculates the pressure correction
� General Information
The module calculates a correction factor to compensate the in?uence of the cylinder counter pressure on
the injected fuel mass. Further, the pressure difference at the injector is calculated for each injection.
Note: The display of arrays depending on NC_NR_INJ_CMB must be done as speci?ed in the de?nition of the
NC?s, depending on NC_NR_IV_PLS is PLS_1/2.., see de?nition of the NC?s.
Note: The following de?ne will be used throughout the spec to denote variables with resolution 1 us or 4�s:
#IF (NC_INJ_TI_RES =1)
#de?ne TI_r TI
#ELSE
#de?ne TI_r TI_4
#ENDIF
cmb = IDX_INJ_CMB
x = IDX_INJ_CYL
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 1S

� General Information
The module calculates a correction factor to compensate the in?uence of the varying pressure difference at
the injector for the MPI rail (FUP_MPI MAP) and the in?uence of the fuel temperature (FAC_TFU_MPI) on the
injected fuel mass for different fuel.

SEG: LV_ST_END==1

INJR, Cylinder shut off (Appl. Inc.)
Import actions:
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSetValue (INOUT <Prm_Lf[NC_NR_BYTE_INJ]>, IN <Prm_Value>)
This action sets value of INJR cylinder logical variables data ?eld
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue (IN <Prm_Lf[NC_NR_BYTE_INJ]>, OUT <Prm_Value>)
This action gets value of INJR cylinder logical variables data ?eld
Exported actions:
ACTION_INJR_UpdInjInhPostClc ( )
This action updates the cylinder shut off interfaces to other aggregates
This module calculates the static cylinder shut off information. The cylinder shut off information from
various functions are collected and a ?nal static cylinder shut off pattern LF_INJ_INH_STAT is calculated.
Note: The display of arrays depending on NC_NR_INJ_CMB is HOM/S, depending on NC_NR_IV_PLS is PLS_
1/2.., see de?nition of the NC?s.
50.17.1 Static Cylinder shut off
� General Information
The information which cylinder has to be shut off static, is coded within LF_INJ_INH_STAT at the cylinder
corresponding position. LF_INJ_INH_STAT is equal to INH_IV but is able to treat up to 16 cylinders.
The Output pattern LF_INJ_INH_STAT or INH_IV are the bitwise OR of all inhibit-patterns. As an example see
below:
Figure 50.17.1:

INJR, Cylinder shut off (Appl. Inc.)
Figure 1:
Special treatment of cylinder shut off at ignition key off:
At engine shut down, when the driver wants a shut down of the engine (LV_IGK 1->0) Injection should
be possible further on for an applicable number of segments.
Hints:
? C_N_MAX_DLY_SDN_IV should be calibrated due to needs of Process monitoring. C_N_MAX_DLY_SDN_
IV << C_N_THD_FCUT_N_LIM_ETC_MON. Process monitoring (ECM2) would dissable the injection in
case of extension of this calibratable engine speed threshold.
? If N > C_N_MAX_DLY_SDN_IV when LV_IGK transposes from 1 to 0, no additional injection will be per-
fomed.
? IF N <C_N_MAX_DLY_SDN_IV and N increases due to the following enabled one combustion, monitoring
will deactivate the Injection via LV_OFF_IV_MON. No more Injection will be performed.
? The calibration of ID_CTR_SEG_DLY_SDN_IV (N, TOIL) to zero disables the functionality. The INJR Aggre-
gate will performe like today.
? The "Injection Off Timer" (Monitoring) will disable the injection power stages after approximately 500 ms.
After that time no injection will be possible anymore.
? The perfomance of a combustion and therefore the generation of torque at LV_IGK = 0 may lead to
different side effects in the engine behaviour, included dangerous ones!
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset all 0
# IF NC_STATE_STST_ENA = 1
# THEN
at ECU_STATE transition SYN_ENG_IGK_ON to RUN_ENG
LV_INJ_LOCK_REQ_TMP = 1
at ECU_STATE transition RUN_ENG to ENG_STOP
LV_INJ_LOCK_REQ_TMP = 0
# ENDIF
at Ignition key off OR engine run to engine stop
IF LV_ES = 1
THEN CTR_SEG_DLY_SDN_IV = 0
ELSE
IF N_32 <= C_N_32_MAX_DLY_SDN_IV
THEN CTR_SEG_DLY_SDN_IV = ID_CTR_SEG_DLY_SDN_IV(TOIL, N)
ELSE CTR_SEG_DLY_SDN_IV = 0
ENDIF
ENDIF
Activation: every engine state
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: #if NLC_ST_ENA_PRE_INJ = 1
then triggering also at first valid tooth and
A2Son / * A2Son only if LV_INJ_DEAC_BACK_ENG = 1 */

INJR uses information from CBMD to determine STATE_INJ_MOD_CMB_SP[cmb] and CBMD-bits of LF_INJ_
CMB_SP[cmb].
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] is an additional injection pulse information for each combustion mode.

Part of the information from CBMD is stored bitwise in CBMD-bits of LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] in order to have
easy access to this information in the injection realization (Appl. Inc.) module of the INJR-aggregate. Further
information which is not given by CBMD can be stored in the NON_CBMD-bits of LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] (e.g.
enabling of retarded pulse-update).
Con?gurations data:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP stores CMBD-bits, NON_CMBD-bits and number of HPDI pulses information as follow:
Number of HPDI Pulses:
NC_NR_INJ_PLS_MASK = 7 Mask for the number of regular pulses only for HPDI.
The number of HPDI pulses are stored bitwise in NC_NR_INJ_PLS_MASK for the ?rst three bits as follow:
 
0 0 1 One HPDI pulse 
0 1 0 Two HPDI pulses 
0 1 1 Three HPDI pulses 
Figure 50.18.1:
CBMD-bits:
NC_IDX_INJ_ST_ENA = 3 :Index of bit for injection in start mode.
NC_IDX_INJ_ST_H_PRS_ENA = 4 :Index of bit for injection in high pressure start mode.
NC_IDX_INJ_CH_ENA = 5 :Index of bit for injection in catalyst heating mode.
NC_IDX_INJ_HPDI_ENA = 6 :Index of bit to indicate that HPDI injection is active.
NC_IDX_INJ_MPI_ENA = 7 :Index of bit to indicate that MPI injection is active.
NC_IDX_INJ_MOD_IGN_ENA = 8 :Bit mask indicating enabled ignition coupling of last
injection pulse; project speci?c value.
NC_IDX_INJ_STST_ENA = 9 :Index of bit for enabling injection in start stop mode.
NON_CBMD-bits:
NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_HPDI_ENA = 14 :Index of bit for activation of retarded pulse update for HPDI.
NC_IDX_RTD_PLS_UPD_MPI_ENA = 15 :Index of bit for activation of retarded pulse update for MPI.
LF_INJ_CMB_SP bits is de?ned as follow:

Figure 50.18.2: LF_INJ_CMB_SP bits de?nition
Note:
Bit0 =>Bit2 : Number of HPDI pulses
Bit3 =>Bit9 : CBMD bits
Bit10 =>Bit13: unused
Bit14 =>Bit15: Non CBMD bits
If the bit value of CBMD bit index of LF_INJ_CMB_SP = 1 = >Injection in corresponding combustion mode
is enabled.
If the bit value of CBMD bit index of LF_INJ_CMB_SP = 0 = >Injection in corresponding combustion mode
disabled.
If the bit value of NON-CBMD bit index of LF_INJ_CMB_SP = 1 = >Retarded pulse update is enabled.
If the bit value of NON-CBMD bit index of LF_INJ_CMB_SP = 0 = >Retarded pulse update is disabled.
Example:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for one HPDI pulse in OPP mode "OPP_1" without retarded pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 1000001 Bin, de?ned as follow:
Bit0: indicates that one HPDI injection pulse is active
Bit6: indicates that HPDI injection is active
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for one HPDI pulse in in OPP mode "OPP_1" with retarded pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 100000001000001 Bin, de?ned as follow:
Bit0: indicates that one HPDI injection pulse is active
Bit6: indicates that HPDI injection is active
Bit14: indicates that retarded pulse update for HPDI is active
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for two HPDI pulses in high pressure start mode ?ST_H_2_S? without re-
tarded pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 1011010 Bin, de?ned as follow:

Bit1: indicates that two HPDI injection pulses are active

LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for one HPDI pulses in low pressure start mode ?ST_L_1? without retarted
pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 1001001 Bin, de?ned as follow:

Bit3: indicates that injection is active for start mode
Bit6: indicates that HPDI injection is active
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for three HPDI pulses in catalyst heating mode ?CH_3_S_2? without re-
tarded pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 1100011 Bin, de?ned as follow:
Bit0, Bit1: indicate that three HPDI injection pulses are active
Bit5: indicates that injection is active for catalyst heating mode
Bit6: indicates that HPDI injection is active
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] calculation for one MPI pulse in OPP mode "OPP_MPI_"1 mode without retarded pulse:
LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] = 10000000 Bin, de?ned as follow:
Bit0: indicates that one HPDI injection pulse is active
Bit7: indicates that MPI injection is active
Note:
- Injection for OPP mode is the default, when all indexes bits are not activated for injection in the
various combustion modes.
- Injection for low pressure start mode is the default, when the index bit is activated only for
injection in start mode.

Full notation Simpli?ed notation

ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue(Prm_Lf, Prm_Value) Prm_Value [=]A PrmLf
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSetValue(Prm_Lf, Prm_Value) PrmLf [=]A Prm_Value
ACTION_INJR_BitCylOr(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = Prm_Lf_1 [OR]A Prm_Lf_2
ACTION_INJR_BitCylAnd(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = Prm_Lf_1 [AND]A Prm_Lf_2
ACTION_INJR_BitCylNot(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = [NOT]A(Prm_Lf_1)
ACTION_INJR_BitCylCopy(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2) Prm_Lf_2 [=]A Prm_Lf_1

/* injection uses information from CBMD to determine STATE_INJ_MOD_CMB_SP[cmb] and CBMD-bits of lf_tmp
= LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb]. STATE_INJ_MOD_CMB_SP[cmb] is just a copy of the combustion mode from CBMD
in order to visualize the combustion mode in INCA. Part of the information from CBMD is stored bitwise
in CBMD-bits of LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] in order to have easy access to this information in the application
incidences of the INJR-aggregate. Further information (not given by CBMD) can be stored in the NON_
CBMD-bits of LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb] (e.g. enabling of retarded pulse-update).
All the information needed for the module "Transfer to IO" must be extractable solely from the pair (STATE_
INJ_MOD_CMB_SP[cmb],LF_INJ_CMB_SP[cmb]) through the function ACTION_INJR_GetInjConfParam (e.g
number of pulses, update-modes and types of pulses, criterion for mode switch). Further information for
the setpoint-modules of INJR can either be extracted from the pair (STATE_INJ_MOD_CMB_SP[cmb],LF_INJ_
CMB_SP[cmb]) through the function ACTION_INJR_GetInjConfParam (like e.g. high-prio-pulse) or through
special variables like LV_IV_RTD_PLS_UPD_ENA. */

50.18.9 Inhibition of combustion modes for injection driver protection due to engine
speed and battery voltage
� General Information
For injector driver thermal protection during multiple injection is required. This is realized with inhibition
of combustion modes for dual and triple injection. NR_PLS_INH_N_VB_INJ delivers allowed number of injection
pulses calculated from IP_NR_PLS_INH_N_VB_INJ depending on engine speed and battery voltage. Depending
on NR_PLS_INH_N_VB_INJ actions are called to inhibit triple or double injection modes

50.18.10 Calculation of Mean Injection Duration
� General Information
TI_MV is produced to indicate the Mean injection duration which is important to create interface for the mea-
sured value blocks (used in DGNC) used by service tool.
TI_MV is equal to the mean value of the sum of DI injection time and MPI injection time for every cylinder.

(1) FOR x = 0 TO (NC_CYL_NR -1)

CTR_ACR_TEST_IV_MPI_EXT[x] = CTR_TEST_MOD_IV_MPI[x]
(1) END FOR
Please note! This for-loop should be realized in SW with a #de?ne. CTR_TEST_MOD_IV_EXT[NC_CYL_NR]
and CTR_TEST_MOD_IV_MPI_EXT[NC_CYL_NR] has to be realized also as a #de?ne for CTR_TEST_MOD_IV and
CTR_TEST_MOD_IV_MPI to preserve resources.

50.18.15 Activation of ignition-injection-sychronization during combustion mode switches
� General Information
This task calculates the 10ms synchronous activation and deactivation of ignition-injection-synchronization.
Note for SW: This task must be calculated before the IGRE aggregate!
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: -
Activation: Always
Deactivation: Not active
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description
#IF NLC_IGN_INJ_SYN_ENA = 1
/* This task calculates the 10ms synchronous activation and deactivation of ignition-injection-synchronization.
It should be called directly after CBMD (setting of idx_cmb_mod_cur) */
if LC_INJ_MOD_SP_MAN_ENA = 1
then
state_tmp = C_STATE_INJ_MOD_CMB_SP_SEQ_MAN[idx_inj_mod_sp_seq_man]
else
state_tmp = Idx_cmb_mod_cur
endif
FOR x = 0 TO NC_CYL_NR - 1 DO
IF STATE_INJ_MOD_CYL_ACT[x] = state_tmp
THEN
LF_IGN_INJ_SYN_DEAC_MOD_SWI[bit x] = 1
ELSE
LF_IGN_INJ_SYN_DEAC_MOD_SWI[bit x] = 0
ENDIF
ENDFOR
LF_IGN_INJ_SYN_DEAC = LF_IGN_INJ_SYN_DEAC_MOD bitwise_and
LF_IGN_INJ_SYN_DEAC_MOD_SWI
#END

ACTION_INJR_FacMffTfuPrj(OUT<PRM_FAC_MFF_TFU_PRJ>)

50.18.19 ACTION_INJR_TiCorPrj
This action calculates injection time with correction factors for COSI off projects. This action is called in ?nal
injection timing module and is activated if "LV_TI_COR_PRJ = 1". Activation via calibration switch "LC_TI_COR_
PRJ".
(1) IF NR_MOD_CUR_IV = 2
(1) THEN /* over pressure current pro?le */
ti_tmp = PRM_TI_IN
(1) ELSE
(2) IF NR_MOD_CUR_IV = 1
(2) THEN /* high pressure current pro?le */
ti_4_h_tmp = PRM_TI_4_IN
# IF NLC_TI_4_COR_TI_4_ENA = 1 /* TI over TI correction functionality */
ti_4_h_tmp = IP_TI_4_COR_TI_4_H(ti_4_h_tmp)

ti_tmp = IP_FAC_N_32_TI_4_H(N_32) * ti_4_h_tmp /* TI correction over engine speed */

ti_4_l_tmp = PRM_TI_4_IN
# IF NLC_TI_4_COR_TI_4_ENA = 1 /* TI over TI correction functionality */
ti_tmp = IP_TI_4_COR_TI_4_L(ti_4_l_tmp)
# ENDIF

FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
General information:
This module calculates sequencing and omissions of injection tasks.
Description:
The notation of task calls is as follows:
Elementname "Name of deepest subchapter relevant for task recurrence"
/* SW call name */
There can be simpli?ed usage of the followingACTION_INJR_BitCyl... actions in order to increase readabil-
ity of speci?cations. Operators "[...]A" can be used instead of the full action name.
Full notation Simpli?ed notation
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGet(Prm_Lf, Prm_Idx_Bit, Prm_Bit) Prm_Bit [=]A PrmLf[bit Prm_Idx_Bit]
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(Prm_Lf, Prm_Idx_Bit, Prm_Bit) PrmLf[bit Prm_Idx_Bit] [=]A Prm_Bit
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue(Prm_Lf, Prm_Value) Prm_Value [=]A PrmLf
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSetValue(Prm_Lf, Prm_Value) PrmLf [=]A Prm_Value
ACTION_INJR_BitCylOr(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = Prm_Lf_1 [OR]A Prm_Lf_2
ACTION_INJR_BitCylAnd(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = Prm_Lf_1 [AND]A Prm_Lf_2
ACTION_INJR_BitCylNot(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf) Prm_Lf = [NOT]A(Prm_Lf_1)
ACTION_INJR_BitCylCopy(Prm_Lf_1, Prm_Lf_2) Prm_Lf_2 [=]A Prm_Lf_1

50.19.5.1 Power stage and injection valve diagnosis during segment task
Formular section:
IF(1) STATE_INJ_DR = "RUN"
THEN(1) /* diagnosis during normal operation */
Injection valve diagnosis:
tmp_lv_inh = ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi_Pre()
for x = 0 to NC_CYL_NR -1
if LF_INJ_BAS_ENA_IV_DIAG[bit x] [=]A 1
then
tmp_injdiag = ACTION_INJR_DiagIvHpdi(tmp_lv_inh, x)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi(tmp_injdiag,x)
endif
endfor
ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi_Post():
LF_INJ_BAS_ENA_IV_DIAG [=]A 0 /* reset injbas trigger */
Cyclic power stage diagnosis:
injr_i?nftrans0__seg(); /* get inputs for PbkCyc diagnosis from IO */
if SEG_NR = 0
then
tmp_lv_inh = ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCyc_Pre()
for p = 0 to NC_PBK_IV_NR-1
tmp_injdiag = ACTION_INJR_DiagPbkCyc(tmp_lv_inh,p)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCyc(tmp_injdiag,p)
endfor
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCycPost()
endif
ENDIF(1)

50.19.6.1 Power stage and injection valve diagnosis during initialisation
The trigger to process the diagnostics is produced by "Transfer to IO" module and handled via ACTION_INJR_
StDiagPbkIv and ACTION_INJR_StDiagIniPbk.
Formular section:
IF(1) LV_DIAG_READY_PBK_IV = 1 /* new diagnosis result is available, message via
action called from Transfer to IO*/
THEN(1)
#IF NC_INJ_SYM_BAS_ERR != 2 AND NLC_INJ_PBK_DIAG_SYM_PAC == 1
#THEN /* for ERRM400 INI symptom is diagnosed with PBK_CYC diagnosis */
Cyclic power stage diagnosis:
tmp_lv_inh = ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCyc_Pre()
for p = 0 to NC_PBK_IV_NR-1
tmp_injdiag = ACTION_INJR_DiagPbkCyc(tmp_lv_inh,p)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCyc(tmp_injdiag,p)
endfor
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkCyc_Post()
#ENDIF
ENDIF(1)
IF(2) LV_DIAG_READY_INI_PBK = 1
THEN(2)
LV_DIAG_READY_INI_PBK = 0
#IF NC_INJ_SYM_BAS_ERR == 2 OR NLC_INJ_PBK_DIAG_SYM_PAC == 0
#THEN /* PBK_INI diagnosis is done only in case of UDGI use */
Initial power stage diagnosis:
tmp_lv_inh = ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkIni_Pre()
for p = 0 to NC_PBK_IV_NR -1
tmp_injdiag = ACTION_INJR_DiagPbkIni(tmp_lv_inh,p)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkIni(tmp_injdiag,p)
endfor
ACTION_INJR_ErrmPbkIni_Post()
#ENDIF
ENDIF(2)

50.19.6.2 Injection valve diagnosis during end of line test
In end of line or garage tests, the IV diagnosis may be requested if the IV diagnosis during EOL is enabled via
LC_IV_DIAG_EOL_ENA.
For the diagnosis, a calibratable static pulse down to 0ms injection time is produced on a chosen cylinder. The
IO-SW returns the IV diagnosis raw values and submits the cylinder number of the diagnosed cylinder at an
EOT-task.
If diagnosis results have been transferred from BSW to ASW, LV_DIAG_READY_IV_EOL will trigger the start of
ASW diagnosis over a handshake action.
IF(1) (LC_IV_DIAG_EOL_ENA AND LV_IV_TEST_MOD_AUTH AND LV_DIAG_READY_IV_EOL) == 1
THEN(1)
LV_DIAG_READY_IV_EOL = 0
tmp_lv_inh = ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi_Pre()
tmp_injdiag = ACTION_INJR_DiagIvHpdi(tmp_lv_inh, NR_CYL_IV_DIAG_EOL_VLD)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi(tmp_injdiag, NR_CYL_IV_DIAG_EOL_VLD)
ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi_Post()
ENDIF(1)
50.19.6.3 Cosi Control Diagnosis
#IF NC_COSI_ENA = 1
#THEN
Call ACTION_INJR_CtlDiagCrvVal
#ENDIF

50.19.16.1 Subsection_Runtime_Optimization
/* Cylinder reduction: */
/* determine number of active cylinders (nr_cyl_clc_red_inj): */
if10 LC_LOAD_CPU_RED_INJ = 1
and CTR_CYL_NR_ST_CLC = 0
and CTR_CYL_NR_STOP_CLC = NC_CYL_NR - 1
and LV_ST_END = 1
then10
LV_INJ_ACT_LOAD_TMP = 1
/* temporary variable, showing that load reduction from INJR is active */
nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp = ID_NR_CYL_CLC_RED_INJ(Input: N_INJ)
else10
LV_INJ_ACT_LOAD_TMP = 0
/* temporary variable, showing that regular load reduction is active */
nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp =
CTR_CYL_NR_STOP_CLC - CTR_CYL_NR_ST_CLC + 1
endif10
/* determine last calculated cylinder (idx_cyl_clc_end_inj): */
if20 LV_INJ_ACT_LOAD_TMP = 0
and nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp != NC_CYL_NR
File: 3070A808.00I
13268Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
INJR, INJR manager
then20/* one or more cylinders of the regular load-reduction are inactive */
idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp = CTR_CYL_NR_STOP_CLC
else20/* load-reduction from INJR or all cylinders from regular load reduction are active */
if21 SEG_NR <C_NR_CYL_OFS_CLC_RED_INJ
then21
idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp =
SEG_NR - C_NR_CYL_OFS_CLC_RED_INJ + NC_CYL_NR
else21
idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp =
SEG_NR - C_NR_CYL_OFS_CLC_RED_INJ
endif21
Endif20
/* determine ?rst calculated cylinder (idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj): */
if30 idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp + 1 <nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp
then30
idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj_tmp =
(idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp + 1 + NC_CYL_NR) - nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp
else30
idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj_tmp =
(idx_cyl_clc_end_inj_tmp + 1) - nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp
endif30
/* consider LF_INJ_CYL_CLC_DI/_TRIG for IDX_CYL_CLC_INJ (cylinder-loop in ACTION_INJR_IdxCylSelFlp) and
?nal value of NR_CYL_CLC_RED_INJ and IDX_CYL_CLC_BEG_INJ */
tmp_nr = 0
LF_CYL_RED_INJ_MASK [=]A 0
for i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR ? 1 do
if idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj_tmp + i >= NC_CYL_NR
then
x = idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj_tmp + i - NC_CYL_NR
else
x = idx_cyl_clc_beg_inj_tmp + i
endif
if ( i <nr_cyl_clc_red_inj_tmp or LF_INJ_CYL_CLC_TRIG[bit x] [=]A 1 )
and LF_INJ_CYL_CLC_DI[bit x] [=]A 0
then
LF_CYL_RED_INJ_MASK[bit x] [=]A 1
IDX_CYL_CLC_INJ[tmp_nr] = x
tmp_nr++
endif
endfor
for i = tmp_nr to NC_CYL_NR ? 1 do
IDX_CYL_CLC_INJ[i] = 0 /* not used elements are set to default value */
Endfor
NR_CYL_CLC_RED_INJ = tmp_nr

50.21.2 Engine Speed Limitation for Injection Driver Protection at low Battery Voltage
VB
� General Information
To prevent the DC/DC Converter from destruction, it is necessary to limit the engine speed in case of low
battery Voltage. The value N_MAX_DR_PROT serves as input for the module Engine Speed Limitation Manager
.
For correct application of IP_N_MAX_DR_PROT see:
Software Speci?cation for GDI Module Hardware (using ATICXXX)
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: -
Activation: Always
Deactivation: If activation not true
Recurrence: Determined by INJR Manager
� Function Description
/* prevent division with zero */
TMP_NR_PLS_CONT_REQ_MAX = MAX(1, NR_INJ_PLS_HPDI_STND)
N__MAX_DR_PROT = IP_N_MAX_DR_PROT(VB) / TMP_NR_PLS_CONT_REQ_MAX
50.21.3 Injection valve over pressure protection
� General Information
In case of fuel pump failure causing full delivery, over current pro?le has to be chosen. Additionally to a realiza-
tion of over current pro?le via fuel pressure comparison, now it also can be realized via FARM.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: #IF NLF_INJ_CUS_FCT_ACT[bit 0] == 1
#THEN
at RST, IGK OFF => ON:
LV_CUR_IV_MOD_CUS_ENA = 0
#ENDIF
Activation: Always
Deactivation: -

In this speci?cation the following functions are handled:
- COSI calculation at beginning of INJR.
- COSI calculation at end of INJR.
- Checking minimal mass fuel quantity values.
- Determine maximal injection time and minimum injection time violation.
In this module the following actions are handled:
- Reset of the bit ?eld which represents the various functionalities of COSI.
- Get the pressure of the working curve.
- Modi?cation of the minimal mass quantity upon successful or erroneous bursting.
- Calculation of the minimal mass fuel quantity.
- preparing the axis of centering/back-centering (Action de?ned in COSI Control)
- Centering/back-centering of TI_0, T_OPEN_0, TI_DIF and TI_EFF, only the action is implemented in this
module but it is brie?y described and called in module "COSI Control".
- Initialization of TI_0 and TI_OPEN.
- Determination of the split pattern which is currently used.
- Determination of the ?rst bursted pulse of the split pattern which is currently used.

Overview
SAQ de?nition:
Apart from MFF, there are additional quantities, that in?uence the injection time as follow:
- pressure difference between rail pressure and pressure inside the cylinder (PRS_DIF)
- pressure waves
- injector or coil temperature
- details of the pervious injection (PREV_INJ)
- separation time of the last injection (DELTA_PREV)
- current pro?le
- density of the fuel
- fuel temperature (TFU)
- fuel type

� Function Description
Subroutine AICOpriv_soi_cosi_?rst_pls(x)
==================================================================
pls = Idx_inj_?rst_pls(x)
IF ( (STATE_PLS_TYP_SP_CYL[0][pls][x] == INJ_PLS_TYP__SOI_TI) or
(STATE_PLS_TYP_SP_CYL[0][pls][x] == INJ_PLS_TYP__TI_T ) )
THEN
SOI_COSI_FIRST_PLS[x] = ANG_INJ[0][pls][x])
ELSE
/* output = ang_inj + ti_4 * fac_n_inj
ang_inj: 0..780H, 0..720, 0.375 �CRK
output (angle): 0..780H, 0..720, 0.375 �CRK
fac_n_inj: 0..FFFFH, 0...374.99389, 0.005722 oCRK/ms
ti_4: 0..FFFFH, 0..262.14 0.004 ms

50.22.3.2 Check toggling of C_STATE_COSI_TOG
Toggling of C_STATE_COSI_TOG is used to trigger the various COSI functionalities, this is done by trigging the
bit ?eld LF_COSI_TOG_TRIG which represents COSI functionalities as follow:
bit 0: recalculate enabling of COSI in module "COSI application incidence"
bit 1: special triggers in module "COSI manager"
bit 2: special triggers regarding to module "signal acquisition"
bit 3: Recalculate working curve-index in module "COSI Appl. Inc."
For initializations, these triggers are set here as different bits of LF_COSI_TOG_TRIG (these are reset by the
respective functionalities).
50.22.3.3 Check mode change
Condition to check mode change is given if:
- Injection modes for combustion state set points is equal to the memorized injection modes for
combustion states set points for COSI ...OR
- Additional injection pulse information for each combustion mode is equal to the additional injection
pulse information for COSI ....OR
- reset ?ag is active (determined by module INJR manager)

Check overall enable/disable
It is important to de?ne the following variables to check overall enabling/disabling of COSI for all
cylinders and all pulses:
Overall enabling of COSI for all cylinders and pulses STATE_COSI_ENA:
0: NOT: nothing is enabled
1: INI: go via IP_TI_EFF_REF
2: NOT_ACQ
3: INI_ACQ: acquisition is done without controlling
4: CTL: control and acquisition are enabled
5: CRV: acquisition is active but actual not used, applied already learned
working curves (history)
Overall disabling of COSI control for all cylinders and pulses STATE_COSI_CTL_DI:
- NOT: nothing is disabled
- BAS: control is disabled because of basic condition
- MOD: control is disabled because of mode
Note that the values e.g. of state_cosi_ena may be changed further below if con?guration errors occur.

Burst relevant variables
The following burst relevant variables are calculated if the enabling of COSI signal acquisition is
active. For more clari?cation, an example is given, in order to simplify understanding of this burst
relevant variables calculation.
Example:
Suppose 3 pulses are existing, the ?rst and third pulses are required to be bursted which
is determined by ID_IDX_COSI_PAT depending on combustion mode de?nition, so the pulse
pattern LF_COSI_PAT = 101.
The mechanism to bursting this pulses is depending on if the pulses are near to each other or far
from each other, which is determined by ID_IDX_COSI_PAT_CHG depending on combustion
mode de?nition, therefore the pulse pattern change (LF_COSI_PAT_CHG) indicates that as follow:
If LF_COSI_PAT_CHG = 000 means pulses are near to each other and bursted as follow:
the ?rst and third pulses will be bursted for cylinder 1 then for cylinder 2 and same for all cylinders.
If LF_COSI_PAT_CHG = 001 means pulses are far from each other and bursted as follow:
starting ?rst with bursting of the ?rst pulse for all cylinders then later with bursting of the third pulse.
The main COSI pulse for bursting (IDX_COSI_MAIN_PLS) is determined by
ID_IDX_COSI_MAIN_PLS which depend on combustion mode de?nition.

Calculate dependent burst-relevant information
Divide total pattern into split patterns (next split pattern starts if there is a 1 at
LF_COSI_PAT_CHG).
Example:
If LF_COSI_PAT_CHG = 000 , that means this pattern will be not divided into spilt pattern, only
one split pattern is existing LF_SPLIT_PAT[0] = 101.
The ?rst bursted pulse of this split pattern is determined by IDX_FIST_BURST[0] = 0 (?rst pulse).
if LF_COSI_PAT_CHG = 101, that means this pattern will be divided into two split patterns as
follow:
LF_SPLIT_PAT[0] = 100 and LF_SPLIT_PAT[1] = 001.
The ?rst bursted pulses of this split patterns are determined as follow:
IDX_FIST_BURST[0] = 0 (?rst pulse) and IDX_FIST_BURST[1] = 2 (third pulse).

Control
Control-relevant variables
The main pulse must be controlled (i.e. it must be 1 in LF_COSI_PAT) - it is mapped to the controller-
index 0, among the other controlled pulse (which have 1 in LF_COSI_PAT, the controller-index is 1
for the smallest controlled pulse, 2 for the next and so on.

50.22.3.5 Determination of the suitable stored working curve
Determination of the suitable working curve in NVMY is done if one of the additional in?uences on the injection
time(SAQ) is outside the window of the actual working curve.
Note: At the moment , only pressure is considered in SAQ.
As it is described in module "COSI Control" the rough shape of the TI_EFF-curves are stored in NVMY over a
wide range of SAQ. This limited number of stored curves are denoted as ?working curves? CRVI.
An example
CRV1 = {PRS_DIF = 60 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV2 = {PRS_DIF = 100 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV3 = {PRS_DIF = 140 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV4 = {PRS_DIF = 200 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
e.g. CRV2 at PRS_DIF = 100 bar covers the pressure range between 80 and 120 bar and the same for the other
curves (including some hysteresis).
Condition for searching the suitable curve from the stored working curve in NVMY:
- cylinder pressure difference is greater than maximum pressure of the actual working curve ...OR
- cylinder pressure difference is less than minimum pressure of the actual working curve

Searching a suitable curve from the stored working curves in NVMY is just done if the pressure
is out of range of the old curve boundaries.
Example:
Is required to ?nd a suitable working curve, which its range include the pressure of 90 bar (CRV2
should be chosen as it covers the pressure range from 80 to 120 bar as shown in pervious example).
So the calculation for searching the suitable curve is done as follow:
Start searching the stored working curves in NVMY. First start with checking CRV1 at pressure of
60 bar which covers the pressure range from 40 to 80 bar and check if the pressure difference lies in
that range. Otherwise index is increased to check the following curve CRV2 at pressure of 100 bar
which cover the pressure range from 80 to 120 bar. As the required pressure of 90 bar is lying in
this range, then a ?ag is set and the loop is terminated.

50.22.3.6 System related MFF correction
The distance between two consecutive pulses on one cylinder may have in?uence on the injected fuel mass.
For very short pulse separation times, too much fuel is injected due to remanence of the injector.
For the calculation of the pulse separation time it is only possible to take injection times and angles from the
last recurrence.
At mode changes injection times and values of the last recurrence are not valid and may produce errors in the
correction calculation. To avoid this, the correction must be 0 in this case.
The fuel mass correction is calculated if
- a pulse is enabled but not as a make up pulse, the correction is not done for make up pulses
- there is no mode change (combustion mode, pulse information, reset)
- a previous pulse was active, the correction is only done for subsequent following pulses
The fuel mass correction is done via an IP relating on the inputs of FUP_H and time distance between two
pulses. To evaluate the distance between two pulses following has to be considered:
- TI_T-Pulse: distance is de?ned by T_DELTA_INJ_4

- T_TI-Pulse: T_DELTA_INJ_4 de?nes distance to next pulse, distance to previous pulse depends on pulse type
of previous pulse
- EOI_TI-/ SOI_TI-Pulses; T-TI-Pulse if previous pulse is not a T_TI-Pulse: distance is de?ned by EOI of previous
pulse to SOI of actual pulse

Note:

tions.
50.22.10 ACTION_INJR_GetLfCosiSplitPat
This action returns the split pattern which is currently used.
Note: At the moment PRM_CYL is not used. In principle, COSI only works if all cylinders have the same basic
strategy (same mode, similar MFF , etc. ).
For Scan function (AD_INI), all requested cylinders must have exactly the same pattern. Otherwise ST_PAT and
ST_LST_PAT are not synchronized and the whole LF_COSI_AD_INI sequence is wrong.
50.22.11 ACTION_INJR_GetIdxFirstBurst
This action returns the ?rst bursted pulse of a split pattern which is currently used.
Note: PRM_CYL is not referenced

(1) IF STATE_COSI_ACQ = "NOT"
(1) THEN
Check toggling
(2) IF LF_COSI_TOG_TRIG[bit 2]
bit 2: special triggers regarding signal acquisition (see de?nition at module COSI AI
section 1.1.2).
(2) THEN
LF_COSI_BSW_ERR_TOT = 0
ACTION_INJR_CosiAcqCal()
/*recalculate signal acquisition parameters (see de?niton at module COSI acquisition) */
ACTION_RstLfCosiTogTrig(2) /* reset bit 2 of LF_COSI_TOG_TRIG */
(2) ENDIF
Check if new burst can be done
tmp_mask_cyl_all = (2 ? NC_CYL_NR) -1 /* set value 1 for each cylinder */
(3) IF LF_COSI_ERR_BAS = 0 AND
STATE_INJ_DR = "RUN" AND
LV_ENA_COSI_ACQ
(3) THEN
tmp_bst =
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue(LF_COSI_BURST_DI_DEAC) BITWISE OR
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue(LF_INJ_INH_ACT)
(3a) IF STATE_COSI_AD_INI >COSI_AD_INI_PREP /*CHK/CHG*/
(3a) THEN
tmp_bst = tmp_bst BITWISE OR
INVERSE(ACTION_INJR_BitCylGetValue(LF_COSI_AD_INI_REQ_CYL))
/* this one is needed because some cylinders might have been removed during scan,
while others are still scanning on */

(3a) ENDIF
tmp_bst = tmp_bst BITWISE AND tmp_mask_cyl_all
(3) ELSE
tmp_bst =tmp_mask_cyl_all
(3) ENDIF
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSetValue(LF_COSI_BURST_DI_BAS, tmp_bst)
/* disables which may occur over a long time */
Require a new burst
(4) IF tmp_bst ?= tmp_mask_cyl_all
(4) THEN
(5) IF call subroutine AICOpriv_MngSetCylPlsBurst(PRM_TRIG) >0
/* determine new cylinder and pulse: IDX_COSI_CYL, LF_COSI_PLS_BURST */
(5) THEN
x = IDX_COSI_CYL
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(LF_COSI_SPLIT_PAT_ACT, x, 1)
NR_COSI_BURST_CYC_ACT = NR_COSI_BURST_CYC[x]
bstcyc = NR_COSI_BURST_CYC_ACT
bstio = 0
pls = 0
DO
(6) IF LF_COSI_PLS_BURST[bit pls]
(6) THEN
LF_COSI_BURST_CYC_PLS_OK[x][bit bstcyc] =1
LF_COSI_BURST_CYC_PLS_AD[x][bit bstcyc] =1
IDX_COSI_PLS[x][bstcyc] = pls
T_COSI_BAS_CYL[x][bstcyc] = C_T_COSI_BAS
bstcyc = bstcyc + 1
bstio = bstio + 1
LF_COSI_PLS_BURST[bit pls] = 0
(6) ENDIF
pls = pls + 1
WHILE pls <NC_NR_IV_PLS AND bstio <NC_NR_COSI_BURST_MOD
NR_COSI_BURST_CYC[x] = bstcyc
(7) IF LF_COSI_PLS_BURST = 0
/* all requested pulses for current cycle are transferred to BSW for cylinder */
(7) THEN
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(LF_COSI_CYL_BURST, x, 0)
/* remove x from the cylinder pool */
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(LF_COSI_END_RNG_DI, x, 1)
/* disable further requests for this cylinder for the current
cycle (released at INJBAS) */
(8) IF STATE_COSI_AD_INI >"PREP" AND
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGet(LF_COSI_AD_INI_REQ_CYL, x)
(8) THEN
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet(LF_COSI_AD_INI_ST_SPLIT_PAT, x, 1)
(9) IF ACTION_INJR_BurstReqLstSplitPat(x)
(9) THEN
ACTION_INJR_BitCylSet
(LF_COSI_AD_INI_ST_LST_SPLIT_PAT, x, 1)
Note: the current AD_INI does not allowed for cylinder
individual split pattern.

FOR bstcyc =

pls = IDX_COSI_PLS[x][bstcyc]

(7a) ENDIF
bstio +1
ENDFOR
bst_request.cyl = x
/* bst_request.pbuffer[0] / size_of_buffer / size_of_burst_result /

tmp_?ag = INFR_INJ_ReqBstMeas( (INFR_INJ_BST_request*)

50.23.7 ACTION_INJR_CosiMngEndRng

50.23.8 ACTION_INJR_CosiMngSetErrBsw
This actions sets the bit error position of the error bit?eld for the basic COSI-BSW.
LF_COSI_BSW_ERR[bit PRM_ERR_PSN] = 1
LF_COSI_BSW_ERR_TOT[bit PRM_ERR_PSN] = 1
De?nitions of the following bits of LF_COSI_BSW_ERR:
-bit 0: bad acknowledge from BSW
-bit 1: wrong number of burst results
-bit 2: wrong channel
-bit 3: wrong event
-bit 4: wrong pulse
-bit 5: wrong start address
-bit 6: burst_samples <nr_sample_inj_burst
-bit 7: burst_samples >NC_NR_COSI_MAX
-bit 8: wrong cylinder
-bit 9: wrong end of burst
-bit 10: ?rst pulse not in pattern (A.I. error)
50.23.9 ACTION_INJR_CosiMngSetErrAdIni
This action sets the bit error position of the error bit?eld of the adaptive initialization (used for scan).
LF_COSI_AD_INI_ERR[bit PRM_ERR_PSN] = 1
De?nitions of the following bits of LF_COSI_AD_INI_ERR:
--bit 3: PREP too long
-bit 4: CYC too long
-bit 6: pressure-deviation too big (of AD_INI-pulse from the mid-pressure of the AD_INI-curve)

� General Information
In this module the ?nal procedure for TI calculation (TI_H) for an arbitrary SAQ?s: Centering, back-centering and
fast bit coded adaptation of the working curves is described.

INJR, COSI control (COSI_CTL)
COSI controlling and acquisition can be con?gured out via compiler switch NC_COSI_ENA.
Overview:
SAQ (Set of Additional Quantities) de?nition:
Apart from MFF, there are additional quantities, that in?uence the injection time as follow:
- pressure difference between rail pressure and pressure inside the cylinder (PRS_DIF)
- pressure waves
- injector or coil temperature
- details of the pervious injection (PREV_INJ)
- separation time of the last injection (DELTA_PREV)
- current pro?le
- density of the fuel
- fuel temperature (TFU)
- fuel type
Introduction of TI_CLOSE:
For a given SAQ, we get a certain T_CLOSE curve with variation of TI. Alternatively TI_CLOSE = TI + T_CLOSE
over TI can be drawn as shown below, which is more advantageous for TI-calculation.
Figure 50.24.1:
The MFF characteristic gives a TI_EFF (as described in module Finial injection timing).
Realizing MFF_REQ means realizing a certain TI_EFF_REQ and ?nally means realizing a certain TI_CLOSE_REQ,
which is done easily in the TI_CLOSE diagram.
Example:
This is done easily see e.g. TI_CLOSE_REQ_1 just go horizontal to hit the TI_CLOSE curve as shown in the ?gure1,
then TI_1 is obtained which realizes TI_CLOSE_REQ_1 and hence the requested MFF_1
NOTE: A problematic occurs due to the presence of the ballistic area as a non-uniqueness of TI?s obtained
while realizing TI_CLOSE.
Example:
TI_CLOSE_REQ_2 can be realized by TI_2a, TI_2b, TI_2c as shown in ?gure1, therefore a fast bit coded adaptation
is introduced to avoid multiple TI?s.

Introduction of TI_EFF-curve (working curves) within (TI_DIF, TI_EFF) coordinate system with the origin
(TI_0, T_OPEN):
For reliable calculation it is necessary to determine the origin points (starting points) of the injector, therefore
a new coordinate system is introduced within axis TI_DIF and TI_EFF corresponding to TI and TI_CLOSE with
origin of TI_0 and T_OPEN
TI_0 : starting time point (calibration constant depending on SAQ) where the ?rst in?nitesimal
opening of the injector is occurred. i.e. the ?rst in?nitesimal MFF, that is MFF = 0 for TI <
TI_0 , MFF?0 for TI ?TI_0.
T_OPEN : time when the injector is totally opened (calibration constant depending on SAQ).
TI_CLOSE_0 is equal to T_OPEN_0 at the injection time TI_0 see ?gure 2.
TI_EFF : is de?ned as the effective injection time TI_EFF = TI_CLOSE - T_OPEN (TI + T_CLOSE -
T_OPEN). So TI_EFF = 0 at TI = TI_0 (begin of ballistic area).
TI_DIF: :is the difference injection time between the injection time and the starting time point
TI_DIF =TI - TI_0
Figure 50.24.2:
Fast bit-coded adaption of the working curves:
To avoid the problem, that TI_EFF varies very much with TI (especially near the ballistic area, there are even
negative gradients, which are very hard to handle by any controller. So, it could be more effectively if at least
the rough shape of the working curve at the given SAQ is known. Therefore a method for quickly ?nding the

INJR, COSI control (COSI_CTL)
right TI "fast bit-coded adaption" is applied to store those rough shapes of the working curve in NVMY and to
avoid the non-uniqueness of TI?s.
The rough shape of the TI_EFF-curves are stored in NVMY over a wide range of SAQ. This limited number of
stored TI_EFF curves are denoted as ?working curves? CRVI.
An example
CRV1 = {PRS_DIF = 60 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV2 = {PRS_DIF = 100 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV3 = {PRS_DIF = 140 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
CRV4 = {PRS_DIF = 200 bar, temperature = RT, DELTA_PREV = very high,..)
e.g. CRV2 at PRS_DIF = 100 bar covers the pressure range between 80 and 120 bar and the same for the other
curves (including some hysteresis).
Procedure of TI-calculation (TI_H):
The TI-calculation is done to re?ect the requested MFF as follow:
- For a given SAQ there is a corresponding working curve stored in NVMY (see the right curve at ?gure3)
- The MFF characteristic yields a TI_EFF_SP (see the left curve at ?gure3 )
- Then go right to hit the working curve which yield a TI_DIF
- TI (TI_H)= TI_DIF + TI_0
- This TI is applied for the current cycle
In case of adaption: T_CLOSE is measured back (described in module COSI-Acquisition) and calculate TI_EFF
= TI + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN_0. immediately the working curve is updated towards the point (TI_DIF, TI_EFF).
Summary: the near history is stored as much as possible and applied for ?nding the right TI.
 �       
Figure 50.24.3:
Adaption:
means the working curve is updated towards the point (TI_DIF, TI_EFF) in order to ?nd the right value of TI and
stored in NVMY if one or more pulses are controlled which is decided by the variable IDX_CTL_COSI.
De?nition of IDX_CTL_COSI:
Controlling index of each pulse (negative means not controlled (not adapted): -1 = use working curves,
-2 = use INI-map, -3 = other current pro?le) for COSI.

INJR, COSI control (COSI_CTL)
Example:
IDX_CTL_COSI = -3 : other current pro?le (without COSI)
IDX_CTL_COSI = -2 : use initialization-maps (IP_TI_EFF_REF)
IDX_CTL_COSI = -1 : main pulse is not controlled (using working curves without adaption)
IDX_CTL_COSI = 0 : main pulse is controlled (using working curves + adaption)
IDX_CTL_COSI > 0 : Additional pulse is controlled (using additional curves + adaption)
Centering / Back-centering of the working curve for an arbitrary SAQ:
As the rough shape of the working curves are stored in NVMY over a wide range of SAQ, example: CRV2 covers
the SAQ range i.e. pressure range between 80 and 120 bar and the same for the other curves. Therefore the
working curve in the mid of the SAQ range has to be determined i.e. at PRS_DIF = 100 bar.
So the working curves for these SAQ?s should be ?normalized? in such a way that the single working curve
can re?ect their shapes as good as possible. Otherwise e.g. the working curve CRV 2 would change a lot
when pressure difference goes from 80 bar to 120 bar and vice versa, and this would cause bad effects on the
TI-calculation, therefore this process is called normalization i.e. Centering / Back-centering.
The normalization of the curve is currently done by scaling of x- and y axis (TI_DIF, TI_EFF) as it described in
module COSI A.I. The normalization of the origin points (TI_0_MID, TI_OPEN_0_MID) varies with the SAQ and it
is stored in NVMY.
Example:
For a given SAQ
- The origin (TI_0_MID, T_OPEN_0_MID) and the working curve have been stored in NVMY
- Left ?gure: using MFF-characteristic, the requested MFF_STND_SP yields TI_EFF_SP
- Middle ?gure: Centering of the working curve
- TI_0_MID, T_OPEN_0_MID (get them from NVMY)
- TI_EFF_SP is centered to TI_EFF_MID_SP
- TI_EFF_MID_SP hit the stored working curve and obtain TI_DIF_MID_SP
- Right ?gure: Back-centering to required SAQ and consider the working curve and its origin
- The stored origin TI_0_MID and T_OPEN_0_MID are back centered to the origin TI_0
and T_OPEN_0
- TI_DIF_MID_SP is back centered to TI_DIF_SP
- TI_EFF_MID_SP is back centered to TI_EFF_SP(same and equal as the one in the left)
- TI (TI_H) = TI_0 + TI_DIF_SP, therefore TI_H is applied to the injector to optimally yield
MFF_STND_SP
In case of adaption: T_CLOSE is measured back (described in module COSI-Acquisition)
- TI_EFF = TI + T_CLOSE - T_OPEN_0 (T_OPEN is constant)
- TI_EFF is centered to TI_EFF_MID
- the working curve is adapted from the original (TI_DIF_MID_SP,
TI_EFF_MID_SP) towards the new points (TI_DIF_MID_SP, TI_EFF_MID_SP)
.

Main TI variables (resolution = 0.1 us):

= 1.2 us for the ?rst12 bytes
= 2.4 us for the next 20 bytes
= 4.8 us for the last 8 bytes

TI_DIF_CRV_MAX : end of working curve (TI_DIF at curve end)

INJR, Injection valve diagnosis MPI
For ATIC39:
A valid diagnosis of all failures can only be detected when the injector was operated at least one time since
the last changes and the ?lter times are observed. A short circuit to plus (SCP) and an open circuit (OC) can be
detected only when the injector is ON . A short circuit to ground (SCG) can be detected only when the injector
is OFF. Otherwise the diagnosis has to be suppressed. This is managed by the calculation of the diagnostic
conditions.
For ATIC92-94, ATIC113, ATIC140:
A short circuit to plus (SCP) can be detected only when the injector is ON . A short circuit to ground (SCG) and
an open circuit (OC) can be detected only when the injector is OFF.

INJR, Injection valve diagnosis
Figure 50.26.1:
The IV diagnosis can be deactivated cylinder individual manually by CLF_IV_HPDI_DIAG_INH_MAN.
In order to avoid sudden torque raises after a limp home occurred and cylinder where shut off due to an
IV error, the healing of this error has to be avoided. Therefore, the diagnosis is inhibited in this case of a
debounced error.
Injection can be inhibited by several aggregates. As it is not guaranteed that ATIC124 delivers correct IV-
diagnosis values if no injection pulse is driven, the IV-diagnosis can be inhibited by calibrating C_TI_THD_INH_
DIAG_IV.
If IV diagnosis during end of line or garage test is enabled (LC_IV_DIAG_EOL_ENA) and requested (LV_IV_TEST_
MOD_AUTH), the IV diagnosis shall always be allowed. If not, the enable conditions are treated as normal.
Formula section:
IF(1) (tmp_lv_inh OR ACTION_INJR_BitCylGet(CLF_IV_HPDI_DIAG_INH_MAN, prm_cyl) OR
ACTION_INJR_BitCylGet(LF_INJ_INH_IV_ERR, prm_cyl) OR
(TI_MES_r[IDX_INJ_PLS_MAIN_CYL_BAS[prm_cyl]] [prm_cyl] <
C_TI_THD_INH_DIAG_IV / NC_INJ_TI_RES)) AND
(LC_IV_DIAG_EOL_ENA AND LV_IV_TEST_MOD_AUTH) == 0
THEN(1) tmp_injdiag = 0

� General Information
The purpose of the injection valve power stage diagnosis is to detect electrical faults of the used ATIC drivers.
The error detection is effected via the ECU hardware and then handled by ASW and forwarded to the error
manager.
We differentiate between the power stage diagnosis during driver initialisation -this happens mainly after ?igni-
tion key on?- and the periodic power stage diagnosis during engine operation.

/*check of "calibration of current comparator not completed error"

ENDIF(5)
/*check of "enabling error"
IF(6) tmp_u16_err bitwise_and INFR_INJ12x_DIAG_INI_ENA_ERROR != 0
THEN(6) tmp_injdiag[bit 19] = 1
ENDIF(6)
/*check of "synchronization-signal from �C is missing"
IF(7) tmp_u16_err bitwise_and INFR_INJ12x_DIAG_INI_SYNC_WARNING != 0
THEN(7) tmp_injdiag[bit 20] = 1
ENDIF(7)
ENDIF(2)
ENDIF(1)

INJR, Boost voltage diagnosis
This diagnosis checks the injectors boost voltage regarding reasonable values, that is between C_VBOOST_
MMV_DIAG_2 and C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_3.
In order to avoid short-termed variations during injection, VBOOST_MMV is generated. It is the moving mean
value on VBOOST during the last 100ms.
The error detection is performed by anti-bouncing.
VBOOST_MMV is a moving mean value of VBOOST over NC_VBOOST_SAVE_MVV samples.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: VBOOST_MMV = 65 V at RST
T_IGK_ON_MIN_DIAG = C_T_IGK_ON_MIN_DIAG_VBOOST at RST OR IGKON
Recurrence: 20 ms
� Function Description
VBOOST_MMV = (VBOOST n?4 + VBOOSTn?3 + VBOOSTn?2 + VBOOSTn?1 + VBOOST) /
5
Figure 50.28.1:
NC_VBOOST_SAVE_MMV = 5
tmp_vboost_mmv = 0
vboost_save[index_saved] = VBOOST
index_saved ++
IF(1) index_saved >= NC_VBOOST_SAVE_MMV
THEN(1) index_saved = 0
ENDIF(1)
FOR(2) (y = 0 TO y < NC_VBOOST_SAVE_MMV; y ++)
tmp_vboost_mmv = tmp_vboost_mmv + vboost_save[y]
ENDFOR(2)
tmp_vboost_mmv = tmp_vboost_mmv / NC_VBOOST_SAVE_MMV
VBOOST_MMV = tmp_vboost_mmv

INJR, Boost voltage diagnosis
50.28.1 ACTION_INJR_DiagVboost
This diagnosis is executed at running engine. After the engine began to run, the diagnosis has to be disabled
for a short time to avoid inaccurate error detection.
De?nition of tmp_injdiag for VBOOST diagnosis:
Figure 50.28.2:
Formula section:
IF(1) LV_ES = 0
THEN(1)
IF(2) T_IGK_ON_MIN_DIAG >0
THEN(2) T_IGK_ON_MIN_DIAG- - //timer decrementation by 300 ms until 0
ENDIF(2)
ENDIF(1)
IF(3) tmp_lv_inh = 1 OR T_IGK_ON_MIN_DIAG >0
THEN(3) tmp_injdiag = 0 // set all cdn and sym to 0
ELSE(3) tmp_injdiag = 7 // = 0111h, all three symptoms are valid
IF(4) VBOOST_MMV <C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_1 //VBOOST to low
THEN(4) tmp_injdiag [bit 16] = 1
ENDIF(4)
IF(5) VBOOST_MMV <= C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_2 //VBOOST low
THEN(5) tmp_injdiag [bit 17] = 1
ENDIF(5)
IF(6) VBOOST_MMV >C_VBOOST_MMV_DIAG_3 //VBOOST high
THEN(6) tmp_injdiag [bit 18] = 1
ENDIF(6)

� General Information
Like the diagnosis actions in the core part of the aggregate, also the INJR Global error handler is structured in
actions. The action call of diagnosis action and error handler action is managed in the INJR Manager.
The INJR Global error handler gets condition and symptoms of the single diagnosis parts via tmp_injdiag, a 32
bit variable. Bit 0 to 15 of tmp_injdiag represent the condition, bit 16 to 31 the error symptom of a diagnosis.

50.29.1 Initialization of global error handler
� General Information
For ERRM4xx diagnosis, the error symptom is stored in a bit mask in the ERRM. In the SW this bit mask is
get via the function call c_fmy_get_err_sym(tmp_err_idx). As the name of the function call would suggest a
calibration variable in this speci?cation, it is replaced by the instruction "ERRM function call, returning bit mask
of symptom[x]".
The tbl_pbk_iv_.. variables are constant ?elds, de?ned in SW but not described in the speci?cation.

PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi
Description of private function:
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi(OUT<lf_state_dgo>, IN<tmp_injdiag>, IN<pos>)
This private function returns the LF_STATE_DGO_... value for the UDGI ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag call.
Formula section:
/*tmp_injdiag: lower 16 bits = cdn, upper 16 bits = err
IF(1) tmp_injdiag[bit [pos]] == 1
THEN(1)
IF(2) tmp_injdiag[bit [pos]+16] == 1
THEN(2) lf_state_dgo = 3 (CDN + SYM)
ELSE(2) lf_state_dgo = 1 (CDN + NO_SYM)
ENDIF(2)
ELSE(1) lf_state_dgo = 0 (NO_CDN)
ENDIF(1)
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_State_Udgi
Description of private function:

INJR, INJR Global error handler
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_State_Udgi (OUT<tmp_state>, IN<mask1>, IN<mask2>, IN<pos>)
This private function returns a status information for an error location in case that an error is present.
Note: tmp_state is u16, mask_1 and mask2 are u16
Note: - function is only called in case of an error (runtime optimization).
- Mask2 is currently only used for IV_HPDI diagnosis. For the other diagnoses, mask2 is set to 0, hence
bit 2 will always be 0.
Status information: bit 0: error is present
Bit 1: symptom masked with mask1 != 0 (used for inhibit information)
Bit 2: symptom masked with mask2 !=0 (used for inhibit information)
Formula section:
tmp_state[bit 0] = 1 /* bit 0 is set */
if (mask1[bit pos]) != 0
then tmp_state[bit 1] = 1
endif
if (mask2[bit pos]) != 0
then tmp_state[bit 2] = 1
endif
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Old_Rgl
Description of private function:
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Old_Rgl(OUT<err_sym>, IN<tmp_injdiag>, IN<nr>, IN<idx_st>)
This private function returns the error symptom for a ERRM4xx regular diagnosis.
Formula section:
/*tmp_injdiag: lower 16 bits = cdn, upper 16 bits = err
/*note: priority of the symptoms is in the given order (bit 0 = highest prio,...)
tmp_vld = ?rst 16 bits of tmp_injdiag
tmp_err = last 16 bits of tmp_injdiag
IF(1) tmp_vld != 0
THEN(1) err_sym = NC_MASK_ERR_CDN_DIAG
/*NC_MASK_ERR_CDN_DIAG = not speci?ed, but in SW available input from ERRM
ELSE(1) err_sym = 0
ENDIF(1)
IF(2) tmp_err[bit [idx_st]] == 1
THEN(2) err_sym = err_sym bitwise_or MASK_ERR_SYM_0
/*MASK_ERR_SYM_0 = not speci?ed, but in SW available input from ERRM
ELSE(2)
IF(3) nr >= 2
THEN(3)
IF(4) tmp_err[bit [idx_st]+1] == 1
THEN(4) err_sym = err_sym bitwise_or MASK_ERR_SYM_1

PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Old_Pbk
Description of private function:
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Old_Pbk(IN<tmp_injdiag>, IN<nr>, IN<idx_st>
This private function returns the error symptom for a ERRM4xx power stage diagnosis.
Power stage diagnosis;
For ERRM 4xx power stage diagnosis, condition and error symptoms a given in blocks per 4 bits to the ERRM
actions. Therefore tmp_injdiag is shifted about [idx_st] bits. tmp_mask represents the number of symptoms
bitwise.
Formula section:
/*tmp_injdiag: lower 16 bits = cdn, upper 16 bits = err
tmp_mask[bit 0 to [nr]-1] = 1 /*creates a mask where X bits are 1 (position 0 to X-1)
cdn_diag_tmp = (tmp_inj_diag [starting from bit [idx_st]]) bitwise_and tmp_mask
err_diag_tmp = (tmp_inj_diag [starting from bit [idx_st]+16]) bitwise_and tmp_mask

INJR, INJR Global error handler
PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_State_Old (OUT<tmp_state>, IN<tmp_err_idx>, IN<mask1>, IN<mask2>, IN<idx_st>)
This private function returns a status information for an error location in case that an error is present.
Note: tmp_state is u16, mask_1 and mask2 are u16
For ERRM4xx diagnosis, the error symptom is stored in a bit mask in the ERRM. In the SW this bit mask is get
via the function call c_fmy_get_err_sym(tmp_err_idx) (THEN(1) here).
The symptom bit mask is bitwise_and masked with the calibration variable, indicating if this symptom should
lead to an injection inhibition. (IF(2) here). As ERRM4xx only stores 4 symptoms, but the calibration variable
has 8 bit, the calibration word must be shifted to the position where the corresponding bit in the symptom bit
mask is located. The distance to shift is given by [idx_st].
Note: - function is only called in case of an error (runtime optimization).
- Mask2 is currently only used for IV_HPDI diagnosis. For the other diagnoses, mask2 is set to 0, hence
bit 2 will always be 0.
Status information: bit 0: error is present
Bit 1: symptom masked with mask1 != 0 (used for cylinder inhibit information)
Bit 2: symptom masked with mask2 !=0 (used for power stage bank inhibit
information)
Formula section:
tmp_state = 1 /* bit 0 is set */
err_sym_tmp = ERRM function call, returning bit mask of symptom[tmp_err_idx]
if err_sym_tmp bitwise_and (mask1[starting from bit [idx_st]]) != 0
then tmp_state[bit 1] = 1
endif
if err_sym_tmp bitwise_and (mask2[starting from bit [idx_st]]) != 0
then tmp_state[bit 2] = 1
endif
50.29.3 ACTION_INJR_ErrmVboostPre
Formula section:
/* Delay of VBOOST diagnosis due to switch off of DC/DC converter.
In some projects DC/DC converter may be switched off, always if the engine is not running. VBOOST diagnosis
has to be delayed. If LV_ES = 0, the timer T_DLY_ES_VBOOST_DIAG will be decreased and VBOOST diagnosis is
inhibited until the timer is 0. With LV_ES = 1 the timer is loaded. */
tmp_lv_inh = LV_ES OR !(LV_CDN_VB_OBD1) OR (T_DLY_ES_VBOOST_DIAG != 0)
IF T_DLY_ES_VBOOST_DIAG >0ms
THEN
T_DLY_ES_VBOOST_DIAG = T_DLY_ES_VBOOST_DIAG - 300ms /* limit to 0ms */
ELSE
Do nothing
ENDIF

50.29.12 ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdi
In dependence of the used ERRM (ERRM4xx or UDGI), the assignment of the error symptom is done via the
private functions. Further, the Error Management communication is done.
For this ERRM400 diagnosis a reduced set of symptoms, and only one IV error is used. All detailed errors
(SCG_H, SCG_L, SCP_H, SCP_L) are not evaluated.
Global SCP and IDT symptom is merged to one common IDT symptom.
For the merge of the condition, the last bit of cdn_diag_tmp value of IDT calculation has to be ORed with the
last bit of cdn_diag_tmp_1 value of SCL, OC, SCG, SCP calculation. As result CDN_DIAG_IV is calculated with
SCL_cdn, OC_cdn, SCG_cdn, (SCP_cdn OR IDT_cdn).
For merge of error symptoms SCP and IDT have to be present with cdn and err, to avoid a cross link of IDT cdn
and SCP err and vice versa.
So ERR_SYM_IV is calculated with SCL_err, OC_err, SCG_err, ((SCP_err AND SCP_cdn) OR (IDT_err AND IDT_
cdn)).
The ENVD output variables will be stored in the freezframe in case of a debounced error. The error manager
will store the actual value of the desired variable in the moment when the error is debounced.
Formula section:
/* calculation of ENVD variables to be stored in freezframe in case of a debounced error */
LF_IV_ERR_RAW_BSW_ENVD_L =
LF_IV_ERR_RAW_BSW [PRM_CYL][bit 0 ... bit 7]
LF_IV_ERR_RAW_BSW_ENVD_H =
LF_IV_ERR_RAW_BSW [PRM_CYL][bit 8 ... bit 15]
LF_IV_ERR_VLD_BSW_ENVD_L =
LF_IV_ERR_VLD_BSW [PRM_CYL][bit 0 ... bit 7]
LF_IV_ERR_VLD_BSW_ENVD_H =
LF_IV_ERR_VLD_BSW [PRM_CYL][bit 8 ... bit 15]
/* visualisation of tmp_injdiag for test purpose */
TMP_INJ_DIAG_IV_HPDI[PRM_CYL] = tmp_injdiag
#IF NC_INJ_SYM_BAS_ERR == 2
#THEN /*UDGI symptom based
/* global error symptoms
lf_state_dgo = PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi(tmp_injdiag, 0)
state_?l_tmp_scp = ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag(NC_IDX_ERR_IV_HPDI_SCP[PRM_CYL],
lf_state_dgo)
lf_state_dgo = PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi(tmp_injdiag, 1)
state_?l_tmp_scg = ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag(NC_IDX_ERR_IV_HPDI_SCG[PRM_CYL],
lf_state_dgo)
lf_state_dgo = PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi(tmp_injdiag, 2)
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag(NC_IDX_ERR_IV_HPDI_OC[PRM_CYL], lf_state_dgo)
lf_state_dgo = PRIV_INJR_Ifadp_Udgi(tmp_injdiag, 3)
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag(NC_IDX_ERR_IV_HPDI_SCL[PRM_CYL], lf_state_dgo)

50.29.13 ACTION_INJR_ErrmIvHpdiPost
System reaction on IV errors:
In this action, the shut off information is calculated.
In case of an IV error, the affected cylinder will be inhibited if the symptom corresponding bit of CLF_INJ_INH_
IV_DI_SYM is 0.
Additionally the whole power stage bank will be shut off if the symptom corresponding bit of CLF_INJ_INH_PBK
is 1.
If a system reaction is requested via LF_INJ_INH_IV_ERR_PRE, the shut off can be delayed for a calibratable
number of segments The reason is to allow debouncing of short cuts on high side on both injectors of an
injector bank (it is only possible to detect an IV error if the corresponding injector is still running).
The ?nal shut off will be released via LF_INJ_INH_IV_ERR.
Further the variables LV_ERR_IV[x], LF_ERR_IV and STATE_ERR_IV are calculated. These are old interface vari-
ables which are still used by some aggregates.

� General Information
The condition raw value shows if valid diagnosis results are available.
Furthermore condition for COSI diagnosis is given only if ignition key is on and engine is running. So, a robust
diagnosis debouncing is ensured. Additional, the diagnosis condition is only given if there is no electrical error
present on the injector or the injection power stage.
If a COSI adaptation error is detected, the injection system will leave COSI controlled state. This leads to a loss
of diagnosis condition for the actual driving cycle.

For CSERS multiple injection diagnosis the check of the injection phase is done with SOI angles for all pulses. If
pulses are EOI based, its SOI value is calculated. Reason for this is, the phase of measured ATIC output pulses
is always SOI based.
50.31.1 Evaluation of injection data
� General Information
Evaluation of injection data is only done one at a segment trigger, only for the cylinder which is selected to be
evaluated.

� Function Description
� Signal ?ow diagram:
For a robust diagnosis, we have to take account segment jitter, jitter of injbas-event (interrupt or task at 180�
after TDC of each cylinder where BSW passes measured values of last injection cycle to ASW), wide ranges of
phasing set points and injection times.
Furthermore, regarding set point variation, different update behaviour is con?gured for different injection
modes. So, the actually executed injection times and phasing of the different pulses usually not match the
respective set points calculated at a certain segment, but depend on the set point variation over several seg-
ments of an injection.
For example:
1) Supposed is SOI = 500�CEK and TI = 3ms and BSW has started the pulse. During execution of the pulse we
get a new set point SOI = 480�CRK, TI = 4ms.
BSW maybe con?gured in such a way that 4ms are applied but SOI = 500�CRK since the pulses had already
started. So we have a mixture of two set points. If the pulse is con?gured as an EOI-pulse, than the EOI would
not correspond to any of the two set points.
2) Supposed is an update between two pulses. The ?rst pulse might be executed according to the ?rst set
point, the second pulse according to the second set point. In update mode "update" the TI difference of the
?rst pulse might be applied to the second pulse. So the second pulse might not correspond to any set point.
3) Supposed is an EOI_TI pulse with EOI = 400�CRK and TI = 5ms. Further, an angular frequency of 10�CRK/1ms
(N=1667/min) is supposed. As result, the set point SOI = 450�CRK. At 430� another set point is requested with
EOI = 420� and TI = 7ms.
BSW will prolong the actually performed pulse to 7ms, so the performed pulse is SOI = 450�CRK, EOI =
380�CRK. This is 20� less than the minimum of both EOI set points and will lead with high probability to
an increment of the error counter.
4) There are lots of cases in terms of pulse collisions, collisions with SOI_LIM, EOI_LIM, maximum injection range
violations in current or past cycles, application of TI_T or T_TI pulses, special update mode con?gurations where
a wrong failure symptom may be detected. So an adequate calibration of the error ratio threshold C_RATIO_
CSERS_INJ_ERR_THD has to be considered
So, the following algorithm is applied for the diagnosis:
LV_CDN_PRE_CSERS_INJ_DIAG must be 1 for at least NC_CYL_NR + 1 segments (no inhibits, same mode for all
cylinders, no electrical defects, ..., see Appl. Inc.). Set points for injection angles and times are sampled over
NC_NR_CL + 1 segments and the respective minimum and maximum values are calculated for each cylinder.
For the error evaluation it is checked if the measured values of injection angles and times are in between [min
- threshold; max + threshold]. If this is not the case, an error counter is incremented.
The ?gure below shows where the sampled set points take place referring to the segment where the evaluation
is done ( typical scenario for a 4-cylinder engine).

INJR, Cold start emission reduction strategy diagnosis for injection
Figure 50.31.1:
The injbas-event of a certain cylinder is 180�CRK after TDC. Here, the BSW passes the measured values of the
last injection cycle to the ASW.
For cylinder 0: SEG_NR = s is the ?rst segment after injbas_0 (?gure above: s = 2).
a) If s is more than 30�CRKafter injbas_0, evaluation is done at segment s = 2 (calibratable via C_SEG_DELTA_
INJ_BAS = 2, yellow line in ?gure above) and set point sampling is done every segment, from 1 up to NC_CYL_NR
+ 1 segments before.
b) If s is less than 30�CRK after injbas_0, evaluation is done at segment s + 1 (= 3 in ?gure above, calibratable
via C_SEG_DELTA_INJ_BAS = 3, green line). Set point sampling is done from 1 up to NC_CYL_NR + 1 segments
before.
So it is guaranteed that the measured values are up-to-date for evaluation (E in ?gure) and that all relevant set
points have been sampled.
As NC_CYL_NR + 1 samples of set points are necessary for the diagnosis evaluation, the injection parameter
of the last segment have to be memorized and used for the next consecutive evaluation cycle again (marked
with M in ?gure above).
Calibration hint for C_SEG_DELTA_INJ_BAS:
For low engine speed, measure CRK_PSN_INJ_BAS_0 and SEG_NR (update rate every segment) in the ap-
plication system. If the biggest value of CRK_PSN_INJ_BAS_0 is smaller than 690�CRK ( note that 0�CRK is
considered as 720�CRK), than set C_SEG_DELTA_INJ_BAS to the respective SEG_NR of the biggest value (= 2 in
the example above).
Otherwise set C_SEG_DELTA_INJ_BAS to the next SEG_NR (= 3 in the example above).
In general always the SEG_NR with CRK_PSN_INJ_BAS_0 nearest <= 690�CRK is calibrated for C_SEG_DELTA_
INJ_BAS.

#IF NC_CSERS_INJ_DIAG_TYP == 2 /*CSERS_INJ diagnosis of electrical signal possible */
#THEN Call ACTION_INJR_IvMesElCor (IN<x>)
Call ACTION_INJR_ChkInjSpEl(IN<x>)
#ENDIF
ENDIF(4)
IF(7) ctr_cdn <= NC_MAX_SEG_CSERS_INJ
THEN(7) ctr_cdn ++
ENDIF(7)
ELSE(1) ctr_cdn = 0
ENDIF(1)
#ENDIF
50.31.2 Acquisition of returned injection data
� General Information
For a comparison of set point values to the actual value, the set point values have to be prepared. Reason for
this is that the set point values are calculated for each segment, but used only once each motor cycle. It is not
known in ASW which set point value is taken in BSW. Therefore, all calculated set points have to be taken into
account.
This is done by storing min and max values of each possible used set point for each single motor cycle. The
acquisition separates set points for cylinders and pulses.
The acquisition is done at segment and at half segment trigger.

THEN(3a)
Call ACTION_INJR_SetIniInjSp(IN<x>)

IF(6) i = 1
THEN(6)
CTR_CSERS_INJ_ACQ_MEM[x] ++
/* counts memorized samples during one segment, is update in seg + half seg */

ENDIF(6)
ENDIF(2)
Call ACTION_INJR_UpdInjSpMinMax(IN<x>) /*calculation of min and max set points of
one engine cycle */
ENDFOR

ANG_MEM_MAX[pls] =

(3)ENDIF

50.31.6 ACTION_INJR_ChkInjSp
An error counter should be incremented exactly one time, if at least one of the following parameters is
wrong:
- injection angle
- injection timing
- number of pulses
Wrong injection angle is detected, if the minimum difference between min and max injection phase set point
and BSW injection phase measurement value for an engine cycle exceeds a calibratable threshold.
Wrong injection timing is detected, if the minimum difference between min and max injection time set point
and BSW injection time measurement value for an engine cycle exceeds a calibratable threshold.
Wrong number of pulses is detected via previous checks if an enabled pulse is not executed and via a check
that BSW injection time measurement does not exceed a threshold for a disabled pulse.
For error evaluation, the error counter is compared relative to the number of combustions which were driven
since the diagnosis started. If the error ratio exceeds a calibratable threshold, the error symptom for CSERS for
multiple injection is set.
The error symptom must not be set before catalyst heating was active for a minimum time.
/* The availability of the whole module with all functions and actions can be con?gured*/
#IF NC_CSERS_INJ_DIAG_TYP != 0
#THEN
Formula section:
CTR_SEG_CH ++ /* SW: limit counter to max value */
tmp_err_?ag = 0
FOR pls = 0 to NC_NR_IV_PLS - 1
IF(1) STATE_UPD_MOD_SP[0][pls] != "Autonomous" AND
STATE_UPD_MOD_SP[0][pls] != "Immediate"
/* exclude all make-up pulses ("Autonomous" and "Immediate") */
THEN(1)
IF(2) LF_INJ_PLS_ENA_SP_CYL[0][x][bit pls] = 1
/* check active pulses */
THEN(2) /* pulse enabled */
tmp_ang = SOI_MES[pls][x]
IF(3) tmp_ang >(ANG_INJ_CSERS_MAX[pls][x] + C_ANG_INJ_CSERS_DELTA_THD) OR
/* phasing error - pulse to early */
tmp_ang <(ANG_INJ_CSERS_MIN[pls][x] - C_ANG_INJ_CSERS_DELTA_THD) OR
/* phasing error - pulse to late*/
TI_MES_4[pls][x] >(TI_4_CSERS_MAX[pls][x] + C_TI_4_CSERS_DELTA_THD) OR
/* timing error - pulse too long*/
TI_MES_4[pls][x] <(TI_4_CSERS_MIN[pls][x] - C_TI_4_CSERS_DELTA_THD)

This action corrects the electrical measured injection valve power stage output values.
The correction is necessary as time delays for start and stop trigger of time and phasing measurement lead
to errors.

Formula section:

TI_MES_EL_COR_4[pls_el][x] = TI_MES_EL_4[pls_el][x] + C_TI_MES_EL_ST_COR
- IP_TI_MES_EL_END_COR(TI_4[0][pls][x])

This action calculates its error symptom in the same way ACTION_INJR_ChkInjSp does. But, in opposite to this,
the diagnosis is done by comparing set points to measured electrical output pulses which were directly driven
by the injection valve power stage bank.

Formula section:

STATE_UPD_MOD_SP[0][pls] != "Immediate"
/* exclude all make-up pulses ("Autonomous" and "Immediate") */
THEN(1)
tmp_ang = SOI_MES_EL_COR[pls_el][x]
IF(3) tmp_ang >(ANG_INJ_CSERS_MAX[pls][x] + C_ANG_INJ_CSERS_DELTA_THD) OR
/* phasing error - pulse to early */
tmp_ang <(ANG_INJ_CSERS_MIN[pls][x] - C_ANG_INJ_CSERS_DELTA_THD) OR
/* phasing error - pulse to late*/
TI_MES_EL_COR_4[pls_el][x] >
(TI_4_CSERS_MAX[pls][x] + C_TI_4_CSERS_DELTA_THD)OR
/* timing error - pulse too long*/
TI_MES_EL_COR_4[pls_el][x] <
(TI_4_CSERS_MIN[pls][x] - C_TI_4_CSERS_DELTA_THD)
/* timing error - pulse too short*/
THEN(3) tmp_err_?ag_el = 1
ENDIF(3)
ENDIF(1)
pls_el ++

50.32.1 Condition calculation of CSERS diagnosis for INJR
� General Information
Pre condition for CSERS multiple injection diagnosis is given if:
- it is not delayed ...AND
- state of injection driver is "RUN" ...AND
- start ended ...AND

This image displays a functional block diagram titled "COSI general architecture overview," which is a common representation used in automotive control system design, often modeled or implemented using tools like Simulink.

## Function

The primary function of this system is to precisely control the fuel injection process in an automotive engine. Specifically, it determines and regulates the opening and closing times of fuel injectors, aiming to achieve a desired effective injection time (`TI_EFF_SP`) by compensating for various influencing factors such as fuel properties, pressure, and injector dynamics. This system operates in a closed-loop manner, using measured feedback to refine its control commands.

## Inputs

*   **MFF_SP**: Mass Fuel Flow Setpoint (input to MFF_SP block, described as "Input from FMSP"). This likely represents the desired mass of fuel to be injected.
*   **FAC_RHO_INJ**: Fuel Density/Injector Factor (input to FAC_RHO_INJ block, described as "Input from FYRL"). This factor likely accounts for fuel density variations or injector flow characteristics.
*   **FAC_TI_BAL**: Injection Time Balancing Factor (input to FAC_TI_BAL block, described as "Input from GYBL"). This factor might be used for cylinder-to-cylinder balancing or other timing adjustments.
*   **PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL**: Calculated Injector Pressure Correction (input to PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL block). This corrects for pressure differences affecting injection.
*   **T_OPEN**: Calibrated Opening Time (input to COSI control). Represents a reference or nominal value for the injector opening delay/duration.
*   **T_CLOSE**: Calibrated Closing Time (input to COSI control). Represents a reference or nominal value for the injector closing delay/duration.
*   **IO-Software/Hardware Interface**: While not explicit named blocks, the "IO - Software" and "Hardware" blocks imply inputs received from the physical hardware (e.g., actual injector feedback, sensor readings) that are processed by the "Acquisition" block.

## Outputs

*   **TI_EFF_SP**: Effective Injection Time Setpoint (output from "Final injection timing"). This is the calculated target duration for fuel injection.
*   **TI_H**: High-Resolution Injection Duration (output from "COSI control" to "IO - Software"). This is the precise command sent to the injector hardware for its opening duration.
*   **TI_MES_H**: Measured High-Resolution Injection Duration (output from "Acquisition" to "IO - Software"). This is the actual measured duration of the injection event.
*   **V_MES**: Measured Duty Voltage (output from "Acquisition" to "IO - Software"). This is a measured voltage, possibly related to the injector driver or feedback from the injector actuation.
*   **IO-Software/Hardware Interface**: The "IO - Software" block sends control signals to the "Hardware" (e.g., injector driver) and receives feedback from it.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the COSI (Control Of System Injection) general architecture can be described in the following steps:

1.  **Standard Mass Fuel Flow Calculation**:
    *   The desired `MFF_SP` (Mass Fuel Flow Setpoint) is multiplied by `FAC_RHO_INJ` (Fuel Density/Injector Factor). This calculation yields `MFF_STND` (Standard Mass Fuel Flow), likely adjusting the base fuel mass demand based on current fuel characteristics.

2.  **Final Injection Timing Determination**:
    *   The `MFF_STND`, along with `FAC_TI_BAL` (Injection Time Balancing Factor) and `PRS_DIF_INJ_CYL` (Calculated Injector Pressure Correction), are fed into the "Final injection timing" block.
    *   This block processes these inputs to determine the `TI_EFF_SP` (Effective Injection Time Setpoint), which is the target duration the fuel injector should be open to deliver the required fuel mass, considering various corrections.

3.  **COSI Control Logic**:
    *   The `TI_EFF_SP` (Desired Effective Injection Time Setpoint) is sent as the primary input to the "COSI control" block.
    *   The "COSI control" block also uses pre-calibrated values for `T_OPEN` (Calibrated Opening Time) and `T_CLOSE` (Calibrated Closing Time), which represent the nominal delays or durations associated with injector mechanics.
    *   Crucially, it receives feedback from the "Acquisition" block: `TI_MES_H` (Measured High-Resolution Injection Duration) and `V_MES` (Measured Duty Voltage).

*   The "COSI control" block also uses pre-calibrated values for `T_OPEN` (Calibrated Opening Time) and `T_CLOSE` (Calibrated Closing Time), which represent the nominal delays or durations associated with injector mechanics.
    *   Crucially, it receives feedback from the "Acquisition" block: `TI_MES_H` (Measured High-Resolution Injection Duration) and `V_MES` (Measured Duty Voltage).
    *   Based on these inputs, `COSI control` implements a closed-loop strategy. It compares the `TI_EFF_SP` with `TI_MES_H` and potentially other internal models or states derived from `V_MES` and the calibrated times (`T_OPEN`, `T_CLOSE`). It then calculates and outputs `TI_H` (High-Resolution Injection Duration), which is the precise command for the injector opening time, aiming to achieve the `TI_EFF_SP` despite dynamic variations and physical tolerances.

4.  **Acquisition of Measured Feedback**:
    *   The "Acquisition" block is responsible for receiving actual sensor data or feedback from the hardware.
    *   It processes these raw signals and outputs `TI_MES_H` (Measured High-Resolution Injection Duration) and `V_MES` (Measured Duty Voltage). These are then fed back to the "COSI control" block, completing the feedback loop.

5.  **IO-Software and Hardware Interface**:
    *   The calculated `TI_H` (Commanded Injection Duration) from "COSI control" is passed to the "IO - Software" block.
    *   Similarly, the measured feedback signals (`TI_MES_H`, `V_MES`) from "Acquisition" are also routed to the "IO - Software" block.
    *   The "IO - Software" block acts as an intermediary, handling communication protocols, signal conditioning, and translation between the higher-level control logic and the physical "Hardware" (e.g., injector drivers, fuel pressure sensors, current sensors). It sends actuation commands to the hardware (e.g., telling the injector to open for `TI_H` duration) and receives raw sensor data from the hardware.
